course.subject: ELEC
course.name: Introduction to Electro-Robot Design
course.description: The course introduces the fundamental knowledge on the design, implementation and evaluation of a robot and its sub-systems. It covers the basic principles of analog and digital circuits as well as robot sensing and control mechanisms.  Students have to apply the knowledge and principles learned to design and build a functional robot by the end of the course. Students who have completed ELEC 2200, ELEC 2350, ELEC 2400, ELEC 2420, or ELEC 3310,  must obtain instructor's approval to take this course.

reviews.author: Gman
reviews.comment_content: Starts off with a little bit of basic physics. Then it'll start to get a little more in depth, talking about: transistors, KCL&KVL, PWM, truth map, K-Map and logic.
reviews.comment_teaching: There are lectures,tutorials and lab sessions held each week. The tutorial was great way to recap the things you've learnt so far during class plus also get some extra notes about the topics. Also, it's pretty beneficial as is it helps you prepare for the up-coming lab assignments. But in our case, the lectures were lagging behind the tutorial sessions.
reviews.comment_grading: There are in-class quizzes in the lecture sessions which account for about 8%. They will be held without notice so it's best to show up for the lectures. There's also the Lab work which accounts for about 22%, a written AND lab midterm which accounts for 20% and 15% respectively and finally the demo which holds 30% of the final grade along with a report which is 5%.
reviews.comment_workload:
In terms of workload, the first few lab sessions are pretty easy as long as you follow the instructions well enough. The workload starts to get rather heavy after lab 7/8, where you and your lab partner need to design and work on the logic for the robot. The amount of debugging that you might need to do depends on the overall complexity and also how well you've designed the logic.

A little tip would be to try to keep it as organized as possible instead of wires going everywhere otherwise debugging will be hell for you and your lab partner.

reviews.author: 3_n
reviews.title: Quite good if you know basic circuity
reviews.comment_content:
Contents involve commonly used electronic components, from diodes to transistors. Also involves KCL and KVL calculation, H-bridge, resistors, and some basic ICs. Later on in the course, they teach us Arduino and some basic C++.

The final project involves building a robot car that follows a white line on a black mat with an Arduino Nano board as the control unit.

If you have taken Physics in HKDSE and have a little bit of programming experience, the materials in this course should not be too hard for you.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I have attended Ki's lecture, and he came across the points pretty well. He likes using hand-drawn notes to teach and gives quite some examples. However, his lesson can be quite boring. Shao's lecture has a better vibe and he (as far as I can remember) told some jokes to enlighten the mood (I don't remember anyone laughing though XD). Please note that the instructors (except Ki) and coordinators have a mainland accent.

Also, worth mentioning that Ki often overruns so make sure you have at least 30 mins to spare after the lesson.

Overall, I believe most if not all instructors are doing a decent job in this lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is pretty good for me. Note that it can be pretty competitive though.

Policy:
Lab 30% (6 Labs in total)
Pop-up Quiz 10% (total 20, only top 60% answers will be recorded)
Lab Exam 15% (around October)
Written Exam 20% (around November)
Project Demo 20% (you get 2 trials, each trial allows you to submit 2 versions of code and 2 attempts per code)
Report 5%

My score:
Overall lab: 30/30
Overall Quiz: 10/10
Lab Exam: 15/15, (μ=12.37, σ=3.02)
Written Exam: 89/100 (μ=71.18, σ=19.86)
Demo: 20/20
Report: 5/5
Final Letter Grade: A (yes, only A)
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload can be quite heavy.

You basically have to attend lectures because of the pop-up quiz, tutorials for details about the lab, and lab for the juicy lab score. Basically, this course will take away 5+ hours every week. The project can be overwhelming if the car doesn't work.

reviews.author: Oscar Leung
reviews.comment_content:
Including basic electric circuits
propositional logic,boolean algebra, KVL,KCL,Arduino programming.
The leap from lectures to final project is too big.
You have no idea what to do after final lecture for the project.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Shen, Shaojie is good, English is among the best.
And very patient to answer our questions, the pace is great also.
The only shiny point of this course.
Fox is a nice bad guy, the final review session is really bad, the TAs are in Read-only mode, they only act as a voice transcript of powerpoint.
reviews.comment_grading:
Online exam --
no allow to use calculator, but they gives us some ugly numbers, hard to calculate.
even you learn the proper logic and ways to solve a question, you still stuck on calculating primary school maths
--Mental maths course
Quiz ---
Quiz are fairly easy, and you can get 100% (15% overall) easily, just make sure you attend every lesson.
Final Project ---
program the whole thing by imagination, simulate how car goes in Tinkercad, no real hand-on the car.
reviews.comment_workload:
Lab----
We have lab every week, the labs and summary sheet are fairly easy. With the help of Tinkercad, they are easily done.
The workload is really low.

reviews.author: meow167
reviews.comment_content:
Lectures in the first month are pretty simple for students who have basic E&M understanding in secondary school, consisting of content about AC/DC, voltage, current, resistance. Then it moves onto more advanced electronic stuff like PWM, transistors, H-bridge, KCL & KVL, logic gates, and K-map.

While lectures focus on concepts, tutorials are practical. Tutorials mostly teach how labs are done and most importantly contain examples for the circuit arrangements.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lectures are boring and honestly unnecessary. The lecturer has a heavy Chinese accent. You will have a much easier time going through the lecture notes yourself during free time.

Likewise, tutorials are also redundant. However, since tutorials are extremely helpful in completing lab tasks, it is highly recommended to attend tutorials if you are having a hard time understanding circuit building.

As for the labs, the helpers are very eager to help students with their questions. Frankly, they have assisted me in a lot of the problems I have encountered during the course.
reviews.comment_grading:
6x Labs (20%)
1x Written Midterm Exam (20%)
1x Lab Midterm Exam (20%)
2x Pop-up Quizzes (10%) (Totally 3 pop-up quizzes but only count the best 2)
1x Final Project Proposal (30%) (Final project is substituted by the final project proposal due to class suspension this semester.)

My score:
Lab 1: 30/30
Lab 2: 30/30
Lab 3: 30/30
Lab 4: 30/30
Lab 5: 40/40
Lab 6: 40/40
Written Midterm: 94/100
Lab Midterm: 20/20
Pop-up Quizzes: 10/10, 10/10, 0/10
Project Proposal: 30/30

Overall score: 98.8/100
Overall grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Overall, the workload is relatively low.

Lectures are skippable except for 3 where there are pop-up quizzes about recently taught topics.

Tutorials are skippable.

Labs are NOT skippable. All labs are counted towards the final score. To get good grades in labs, you need to study the tutorial notes beforehand and be very careful in completing the lab report during the labs.

The written midterm is not particularly hard, yet it still demands a bit of preparation. Having a complete understanding of all the lecture notes and finishing 1 to 2 past papers are very sufficient in getting above 90% marks.

The lab midterm is very simple if you can do the labs.

The final project proposal requires students to propose a working plan for the replaced project, with a maximum limit of 2000 words in 6 pages.

reviews.author: Natcha
reviews.title: COURSE BASED ON LUCK
reviews.comment_content: The content of this course is straightforward. You learn about components of the robot that will ultimately lead you to the final project. We covered topics like electronic components, energy, KCL & KVL, DC power, transistor, H-bridge, PWM control, sensors, logics, and the Arduino code. The powerpoint given makes the content extremely easy to follow.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lectures are a little boring but since they are only 50 minutes, it is tolerable. Professor Murch's voice is clear but some of the content might be covered too fast it is hard to understand. The professor will always ask if we have any questions and replies to emails quickly. The powerpoint slides are great and if you miss any lectures you would most likely still understand the content. My TA is Yi Meng and she recaps what is taught in the lectures and prepare us for the labs.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab: 6 Lab Assignments (30% total).
Quiz: Pop-up In-class Quizzes (open book, 10% total), online submission in iPRS (20 questions in total, only the top 60% answers will be counted).
Exam: On-line Exam (close book, 35%).
Project: Project Demo (20%) and Report (5%).

The lab was extremely easy to complete as answers are provided in the powerpoint in the tutorials. Most students get a full score here. For the pop quizzes, if you pay attention to the lectures, you should do fine. As for the exam, I thought I prepared well but I still find it challenging. The exam was divided into MCQ, FRQ, and Tinkercad circuit test. For the last part, it is either you get the points or not and it is worth 20 percent of the test. I forgot to put a wire to connect the GND to GND which costed me 20 marks. The project is also a complete nightmare. You are supposed to write a code for a robot to make it complete the tasks and earn points. However, much of the part is based on luck since various factors can affect how much your robot performs and there's only a few chances you can debug your code and test it out. It really depends on luck if your robot works. I used the same code many times and got different results. You also need to write a report at the end.

My scores:
Lab: Full
Quiz: Full
Exam: 47.67/100 (mean: 71.40, SD: 20.09)
Lab: 18/20
Report 5/5

Turns out I got a B-. I think the grading is pretty good considering my extremely poor exam score. Overall, the content of the course is interesting. However, if you aim for a great score and don't want to suffer with the project, don't choose it.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is average for a 4 credit course. There is a lab that you have to complete every week. I think it should take around 2 hours. The professor might also release some homework for practice but it is not required that you submit it. The worst part would be stressing about the project since there's only a few chances to test the code and you really have to make sure that there are no mistakes. The project report has a minimum of 1200 words. You can finish it in one day.

reviews.author: whyhub1
reviews.comment_content:
The titles of the slides are:

01 Introduction
02 Components
03 Energy

05 Pulse Generation

reviews.comment_teaching: The lectures are alright(at least not boring). Professor Shen tries his best to answer all questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
The content is way too easy. Almost everyone got full marks in everything; the lab exam is the only thing with discrimination. That is, you're screwed if you didn't do well in the lab exam.

20% lab exam
20% written exam
20% lab assignments
10% pop quiz (best 2 out of 3)
30% project proposal (the mean is 28 out of 30 !!)

I got 92.83 (lost 7 marks in the lab exam) in the end and that's a B+.
reviews.comment_workload: The final project was replaced by a six-page report this term due to the protests. Thus, the workload was very very light.

reviews.author: app_Sci
reviews.title: Good grade? Only if you are careful and smart. Think Twice.
reviews.comment_content:
The course starts with very basic physics stuff, V=IR, W=VI, etc.
Then the contents advance to more electrical field, transistors, resistors, capacitors, timers, pulse-width modulation (PWM), KCL and KVL are contents covered before the midterm.
After midterm, logic gates, boolean algebra and flip flops, finite state machines are also introduced.
reviews.comment_teaching: Song is a very nice professor. He teaches with heart, and is willing to answer any questions (course relavent or irrelevant, both OK). He uses handwritten notes for the class instead of PPTs.
reviews.comment_grading:
It has been said that course has a very good grade because lots of people get a good grade in this course (B+, A-, A, etc.)
8% - Pop quizzes in class
22% - Lab sessions
25% - Final Demo
5% - Final Demo Interview
5% - Report
20% - Written Midterm
15% - Lab Midterm
Every coin has its two sides.
Because the contents are easy, the midterm thus have a very high mean for both the lab and midterm.
the mean for written midterm is around 70/100, because most contents were easy. mean for lab midterm was around 9.5/15.
Because there are so many students with good marks, if you fail to review some parts of the lecture notes or you screwed up the midterm due to some reason, you will easily get below mean for midterm.
REMEMBER TO REVIEW KCL AND KVL!!!!!!!!!
You may also encounter stupid mistakes such as forgetting to turn on DC during lab midterm, which costs lots of marks.
The final demo really depends on luck. My car was able to have a perfect run before the demo 9 out of 10 times. But somehow my car cannot turn at the Y splits and oscillates there, which caused my demo to be a complete disaster. It was too dependent on luck.
I got an extremely bad grade at the end. Minor mistakes and random luck could cost a lot in this course as lots of them could outperfom you.
My review might be biased, but it is exactly what I experienced in the course.
reviews.comment_workload:
Before midterm, the workload is not too much. Just review on the important parts and you should be OK.
After the midterms, the main source of workload come from the project that you will do.
You are required to do a car. Details are covered in other reviews.
But however, the results are not always satisfactory, and it is too dependent on luck.

reviews.author: heheheheee
reviews.title: Not a very good grade course
reviews.comment_content: Energy & Power, KCL & KVL, DC Regulation, Transistor, H-bridge, DC Motors(DSE stuff), Pulse & PWM, Logic and Boolean algebra

Overall: 93.1%(B+)
Important: getting 8x% may result in a C range in this semester !!!!!!!!!

Harsh, and trash.......

reviews.author: Dicaprio
reviews.title: Good course but not recommended when online
reviews.comment_content:
teaches basic electronics and Arduino car coding

week 1~6 (lecture 1~12) ACHUTAVARRIER PRASAD, Vinod teaches basic electronics, the resistance, KCL, KVL, is similar to those in PHYS 1114. there are also transistors, capacitors but just the simple part of it.
week 7~8 (lecture 13~15) YANG, Yansong teaches simple arduino code and simple line following robot things.

week 2~7: one lab assignment per week. it is based on what they have taught in the lecture so it is simple. the TA will teach you how to do it in tutorials. lab assignments is checked by your 4~5 pages (mostly screenshots that takes up many spaces) pdf file and Tinkercad simulation shown in the lab session. 2 hours will be enough to complete the lab.

week 9~12: project demo and report. (no lectures, no tutorials, only lab sessions) 2 light sensors (1/0) line follower Arduino robot. 1 light sensor faces the front as obstacle detection.
Full online semester so we submit our code, TA upload your code to their robot, and show the result to you through Zoom. So, you only get limited number of trials.
Therr are 4 weeks of testing, each week 2 code versions, each version 2 trials = 16 trials in total. (the 2 code versions are submitted before testing so you can't modify the second code version after testing the first one. So, one small error may cost you 4 trials)
reviews.comment_teaching:
nice teaching. there might be some accent but it is quite clear and easily understood by me.

the TAs are really helpful. they answer all my questions clearly.
reviews.comment_grading:
6 lab assignments using Tinkercad (30%)
10 popup iPRS quizzes in random lectures for attendance (20 questions, count top 60%) (10%)
a very late mid-term exam (late-April, ~week 10) (35%)
project demo (code your Arduino line follower with limited trials) (20%)
min 1200 words, max 6 pages project report (5%)

the project demo is purely based on luck. it depends on whether you guessed the correct numbers for your code. my lack is bad so I only get 12/20 in project demo. got B+ due to this.
reviews.comment_workload:
two separate 1 hour lectures, a 1 hour tutorial and a 3 hours lab session per week is what written in the time table of the course.

However, there are just 8~9 weeks of lectures (one normal semester has 12~13 weeks). Tutorial teaches you how to finish your lab assignment, which you can just skip it. And you just need to use 5 minutes in the 3 hours lab session to show your lab assignment to the TA and you are free to go. the workload is really light.

reviews.comment_content:

reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is fine. Other than the content on the slides, the professor gives out examples to help us understand better. Two pop quizzes are given every lecture, and the questions are quite easy, just make sure to follow what the professor is teaching.

The TAs in the lab were kind and patient to help us whenever we had questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
30% Lab assignments
15% Pop quiz (best 70% will be counted)
30% Online exam
20% Project demo
5% Project report

I would say the grading isn't that good, because almost everyone got full marks in labs, quizzes, and the final project. The only difference is in the online exam.

My grades:
Lab:29.9/30
Quiz:15/15
Exam:92.5/100
Demo:20/20
Report:5/5

My total score was 97.65, and I got an A.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload, in the beginning, isn't that much. Mostly just spending some time reviewing the lectures. After the online exam, we start to do the final project. During the project period, the workload will be heavier. There will be more time spent on testing and debugging Arduino code.

reviews.comment_content:
Quite easy if you have learned physics in secondary school.

reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is quite except the strong accent of the English of the professor.
reviews.comment_grading:
It is difficult to get an A range as the content is quite easy. You need to be very careful in the exam as you may lose the chance to get an A range
when you get 1 mc wrong.

I got B at around  88.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is very low .You just need to finish your lab report in your laboratory lesson .The final project is the main workload in this course.The report of this project is easy but you need so much time to design your robot .

reviews.author: uxgl7
reviews.title: a challenging course
reviews.comment_content:
ELEC1100 is designed to provide the fundamental knowledge in electrical engineering, basic electronic components and skills needed for the design, implementation and evaluation of a robot and its subsystems.
It covers the basic electronic engineering principle and techniques.
Hands-on laboratory sessions, complemented with lectures and tutorials, are provided to allow students to have a systematic view of the electronic engineering principles.
Students apply the knowledge and principles learnt to design and build a functional robot by themselves.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is fine. To be honest, reviewing the notes by yourself after class maybe more useful.
TA Tang is really a nice and patient teacher.She helps me solve many academic problems.  If you can speak mandarin, you can ask her questions in Chinese!
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab: 6 Lab Assignments (30% total).
Quiz: Pop-up In-class Quizzes (open book, 15% total), online submission in iPRS, only the top 70% of your performance will be counted.
Exam: On-line Exam (close book, 30%).
Project: Project Demo (20%) and report (5%).
My grade:
Lab:29.9/30
Quiz:15/15
Exam:98.33/100
Project:Demo:19/20  report:5/5
overall:98.399% A+
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is very heavy especially during the final project period. I have spent almost 20 hours finishing building the robot car. When you write your codes, you have to run the car for many times so that you can make the data more precise. That is very time-consuming. Even though the car is perfect when you test it , it could go wrong in your early and final demo. So leave it all to the god! Anyway, remember to save the original version when you modify your data. Because later you will find the codes you write at the beginning are the most perfect ones.

reviews.author: kht0124
reviews.comment_content: Content is pretty easy, just refer to other comments for more details.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is fine, it is not particular useful. Revising the lecture notes and do some past papers is enough for a decent score.
reviews.comment_grading: Although the content is easy, as well as the midterm exam, everyone get a very high score and even full marks. Just because you get a 9X% score doesn't mean you can get a A or A+.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is pretty low before the midterm, all you need to do is attend the lessons and answer the pop-up quizzes. After midterm, you need to build a car. Remember to find a good groupmate though.

reviews.author: Cliooo
reviews.title: interesting course

reviews.comment_teaching:

reviews.author: benbenLUCKYust
reviews.title: Online mode is like gambling mode
reviews.comment_content:
!!!Online mode alert¡¡¡

Lectures condensed
1. Basic electronic components with some basic physics in electricity
2. Pse generation and PWM control with timer components

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Vinod Prasad is a funny professor. He also taught us with patience.
My TA was Tang Yimeng (eetangy), who is also a nice person.
reviews.comment_grading: I would say the cutoffs of this courses are high. I only got A- with an overall score of over 90%. Relatively speaking, the content are not difficult, and so the challenging part is about carelessness. In addition, if you have sources like past paper, make sure you finish them, understand them and better memorize them.
reviews.comment_workload: Not that high workload if you have experience in electronics, circuit and Arduino. My roommate even got A+, with no past experience. The world is unfair :(

reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor teaches the lecture and TAs are responsible for the labs and tutorials.

Professor Park's English is very fluent as he studied in the US, and he gives lectures clearly; everyone had no problem understanding the contents. He is also willing to answer questions and help students.

Fox also gives good tutorials. You can benefit a lot by asking him questions, which he answers back really quickly. Overall very good TA.

The coding project is the tough one. You only get two testing sections, and if both of them doesn't work, you simply get a zero.

reviews.author: VintKwan

final grade:A-

The focus is on the final project, which will be difficult for those unfamiliar with C++.

reviews.author: Alex Du
reviews.title: You basically do not want to take this course
reviews.comment_content: Yeah man content is all the same. The problem for the content is that it is too simple and too shallow so that everyone learned well. Seriously, I do not quite get the point of this course being one of the must courses. In UMich, or U Washington, or Stanford or MIT or U Tokyo, people go to ELEC2400 or half ELEC2200+half ELEC2400 equivalent courses directly. Why do we specifically bother to have to take this course?
reviews.comment_teaching: Ross Murch is the professor that I like most. He taught very well, and I took his course over the entire year. Yimeng was also good. She responded emails very quickly and answers to all kinds of question with joy and patience. Even people who never thought about ECE may be attracted to this major only because of them.
reviews.comment_grading:
Unreasonable.
This could be the only comment.
Now, if a course is easy, people score high; and then a luck game came along so the grade only depended on luck. I got 90% in midterm and the mean was 64%, but only got 12/20 in the project. These are the only two places where I got score deduction, and guess what? 89 overall makes B+.
In my humble opinion, this course should either emphasize more in the exams or make more scientific judgement on grades(for instance, absolute grading).
reviews.comment_workload: Not very appealing since labs every week.

reviews.author: ricecrackie
reviews.title: 20% of your grade purely based on luck if you take in online mode
reviews.comment_content:
The same as what others just mentioned
Electric circuit components
Energy (Formulas like P=VI, resistance in parallel/series)
DC Power Source
Pulse generation
PWM Control (The concept of this part is very complicated, especially in the exam)
Transistor and H Bridge (NPN, PNP, nothing special)
KCL, KVL (Popular topics in the exam, make sure you understand how to apply)
Sensors (Nothing special)
Logic and K map (Easy if you have some programming sense)
Arduino code (Not covered in the exam)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor of L1 and L2 is ACHUTAVARRIER PRASAD, Vinod
Not sure why his name doesn't show up
He has an Indian accent, but still can understand what he said
He is a friendly professor. He would greet students in the zoom meeting before the lesson starts.
He is willing to answer our question and explain the concepts clearly, even though this would delay the course progress
For Dr Tang, she is a responsible and friendly TA. She is willing to answer questions and explain the lab in the tutorial session.

However, when it comes to the project code, what both of them advise is inadequate, misleading, confusing, and unhelpful.
reviews.comment_grading:
I rate a D for the project. ITS A NIGHTMARE!!! Others are fine. They deserve a B.
15% In-class quizzes (Count top 70%)
30% Lab
30% Exam
20% Project code
5% Project report
Quizzes and labs are fine. You can get full mark for both if you pay attention.
For the exam, if you want to get above mean, do all past papers and exercises they have given you.
For the project, we only have 3 demo sessions in which we can submit 2 versions of code every demo. In other words, we only got 3 chances to know how our code would perform. It is purely based on luck because the result can be different for the same code, and they will only try your code once (if you submitted 2 codes. Normally everyone would submit 2 cuz we arent confident about our code).  IF YOU ARE MISLED BY THE PROFESSOR AND TA, YOU WOULD WASTE YOUR TRIAL CHANCES.
BE CAREFUL IF YOU WANT TO USE DELAY
My marks
Quiz: full
Lab: full
exam: 70.92 (mean: 64.68, SD: 21.29)
Project code: 18/20
Project report: 4.5/5
Grade: B+
reviews.comment_workload:
Not much. Tinkercad is easy to get used to. Quizzes are fine if you paid attention. Only the exam needs some effort.
There is nothing you can do about the project.

reviews.author: isaacso
reviews.title: Online mode fall 2020- 2021
reviews.comment_content:
Lecture 01: Introduction
Lecture 02: Components (electrical components e.g.transistor,diode)

Lecture 03: Energy
Lecture 04: DC_Power_Source

~Lecture 05-12 is heavily focused, especially L7: KCL & KVL~

Lecture 05: Pulse_Generation
Lecture 06: PWM_Control

Lecture 07: KCL_KVL
Lecture 08: Transistor

Lecture 09:Hbridge
Lecture 10:Sensors

Lecture 11:Logics
Lecture 12 :Kmap

Lecture 13:MCU_Arduino
Lecture 14:Arduino Code_Part I

Lecture 15:Arduino Code_Part II
Lecture 16:Path_Planning_Basics

Lecture 17:Final Project
Lecture 18:Online Exam Review
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lectures: Professor Park does research on Control and Robotic Systems (CRS) and he is absolutely a beast. B.S. in electrical engineering  MIT, Ph.D. in applied mathematics  Harvard University. As he studies in the US, his English is fluent and clear. Overall excellent in Lectures.

The labs and tutorial are excellent as Fox is there. His teaching is accurate. The best thing is that he can give you the right answer even your question is wrong XD.

However, the TAs that teach the last tutorials are bad, they are obviously not well prepared: their teaching was wrong and stopped by Fox). And for TAs in labs, some times we're having some trouble in communication in english.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading depends.

The quizzes are quite difficult as it ends in just a few minutes.

The exam is quite difficult and heavily focus on KCV, transistors (The parts involve lots of maths....). Questions like K-map are being ignored, I guess it is due to the Online mode.
The coding project is not appropriate, we just have 2 times to test and debug. If your code is bad, you will just waste another chance and have no chance to adjust.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite heavy, the labs are fine, the coding project is also fine, but requires a report but all the workload is concentrated at the mid-term period, the final exam period is surprisingly better.

Labs: 6 Lab Assignments (30% total); online submission
Quiz: 4 Pop-up In-class quizzes (open book, 15% total).
Best 3 out of 4 will be counted.

Exam: 1 Online Exam (30%);
Project (mixed-mode):
Coding Project (20%) and Project Report (5%)

reviews.author: Asagami Fujino
reviews.title: DO NOT take it online!
reviews.comment_content:
Something of everything.
From basic electronics like breadboards, components to IC, logic, K-map, and C++ (Arduino, but that's not much different) the course does not dive deep into them.
To be honest, this course is just a programming course (for the final project) as you cannot go to the lab to build the robot and they don't send the materials to you.
What's worse, you have only one chance to test your code before the 'real' demo and that is horrible!

This is the main reason why you should NOT take it online. Since you can't build the robot yourself, this course simply becomes a programming course and has lost all its original purposes! While you're struggling to make the robot to cross the first split, some programming geniuses can already make a perfect run!

If you insist on taking it, you may need to figure out some strategies (like writing a simulator yourself? XD)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Shaojie actually just read the slides in class and add something else. But not bad.
The TA(Fox) is quite responsible and the tutorial is quite good.
reviews.comment_grading:
Labs: 6 labs (30%)
Quiz 4 pop-up quizzes in class (15%), count 3 highest out of 4.
Exam: 30%
Project: Demo (20%) Report(5%)

Labs ~ 29.9% (got 0.1 deducted in a report)
Quiz: full mark ~ 15%
Exam: ~ 24.9%
  - mean: 66.55
  - SD: 16.52
  - my score: 83 (exactly mean + 1 sd XD)
Project demo: 14/20 ~ 14% (I'm not sure if the weight of the demo is adjusted)
Report: full 5%

Overall: A+ (about 88.8)

Labs, quizzes, and project reports are just giveaways if you are careful enough.
The exam is a bit difficult, and you don't nearly have past papers! (only some questions to review)
The final project is the most ridiculous part! Some can get 20/20 while others may only get 3/20 and some 0/20! and  I'm lucky to get 14/20.
reviews.comment_workload: Since we're online, the 3hr lab actually takes you around 15mins. And the labs become homework, so you need to finish them before your lab section. It may take you around 2 hours to finish each lab (and it also depends on your network connections to Tinkercad)

reviews.author: garbage
reviews.title: Disaster course for online delivery.
reviews.comment_content:
The introduction of most of the fields in electrical engineering.
Logics and Arduino coding and stuff.
Making a fucking car.
reviews.comment_teaching: Average teaching. Don't expect understanding all the stuff during the lectures. You would have a clearer view of the content taught in the lectures after taking Fox's tutorial sessions.
reviews.comment_grading:
I give this an E because it is unpredictable. It depends on your luck if you are new to making a robot car.
-----------------------------------------------------
UPDATE:
I take back what I have said and give it a B.
I got 89/100 for the mid-term (Which is about 1.3 sd above mean. ) and 15/20 for the final trial of the project while having the rest of them full mark, AND GOT AN A+!
It is absolutely overwhelming because I just could not imagine getting an A+ in this course without having a single perfect run, WHAAAAAAT?
But I still do not want to give this part A because this course just made me so so so so miserable at the end of the semester. Q_Q
reviews.comment_workload:
I give this a D because of the pain it brought me.
Making a car to run the tracks with your imagination solely during the online delivery mode. This course has always been a pain in the arse for me during this semester. I have sworn for about a million times while writing the Arduino code.
The main workload of this course is just staring at your code wondering what have went wrong while doing basically nothing about them. Because you cannot predict what would happen in the formal trials. This is really very so stressful and you can do nothing about it.

reviews.author: dogu
reviews.title: Great Course
reviews.comment_content: Nice introduction. Easy topics, if you have any previous knowledge it is a piece of cake.
reviews.comment_teaching: Ross knows the topic by heart and he is very nice.
reviews.comment_grading: In online education mode, you write the code for line tracker robot remotely and you don't have many testing chances. So you can get a low grade on the final project.
reviews.comment_workload:
Exams are easy.
Have labs all week, they are easy to do as well.
There is a time consuming final project (line tracker car) with a final report as well.

reviews.author: Max_Hung
reviews.title: A very inspiring course
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers:
1.high school electronics like voltage, current, resistance, energy, and power
2.DC power source efficiency
3.PWM generation and control using given integrated circuit components
4.transistors and H-bridge
5.KCL & KVL
6.logics and K-Map
7.Sequential logic circuit for basic components of computers
8. basic programming knowledge for embedded programming using Arduino

All the things besides sequential logic and programming will be covered in the lab midterm, written exam.
All the things covered in the lecture are VERY USEFUL in the final project.
The first lab familiarizes you with the lab equipment like the DC power source, function generator, and oscilloscope (which are VERY COOL)!
The rest of the labs teaches you to build the robot for the project STEP-BY-STEP
The final project requires you to build a robot that is able to follow a path on a mat.
reviews.comment_teaching:
EMMM, honestly professor SHAO is not really a good lecturer. His accent is a little bit heavy, and I need to get really focused to understand what he speaks, and his lecture is not attractive. I did not skip lectures just because of the pop-up quizzes. Self-studying with the lecture notes is absolutely possible, cause that was what I did.
The TA in the lab sections are AWESOME. They are helpful and willing to help the students to debug. The process of debugging is also interesting. You can learn so much from the lab.
reviews.comment_grading:
Exams: 1 Lab Midterm (20%) and 1 Written Exam (20%)
Labs: 6 Lab Assignments (20% total); minimum 4 labs’ attendance to be eligible for final project demo.
Quiz: 3 Pop-up In-class quizzes (open book);  only the top 2 max scores will be counted (10% total)
Project proposal (which should be report under normal circumstances)(30%)

For the lab midterm, just go through the review questions and lecture notes. Be CAREFUL when you are building the circuit and make measurements frequently, otherwise, you might lose tons of points.

The written exam covers everything taught in lectures besides the programming stuff.  Go through review questions and past papers, especially those about KCL and KVL. I lost most of my points on KCL and KVL but still get a score slightly above 90.

The lab assignments are lab reports that require you to take measurements and do simple math. It should be submitted before the lab section ends. You can take most of the points as long as you follow the steps in the lab manual. I highly recommend read the lab manual before the lab so that you can have adequate time for debugging.

The pop-up quizzes are very easy. Just make sure you can understand the concepts on the lectures notes.

The final project demo (proposal this term) is what makes the difference in grades. Many people lose points because of the final demo. Make sure your robot can satisfy the requirements with different voltage!

I get a score slightly above 90 in lab midterm and written exam, and I get most of the points from other sections! I get an A in this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
THERE IS NO ASSIGNMENT!!!!!!
You just need to spend some time reviewing the course materials after each lecture and before the exams.
Oh, do not forget to preview the lab manuals.

reviews.author: Justin Li
reviews.title: Engineering core course with real workload
reviews.comment_content:
This is an introductory course on electronics and robotics and suitable for any students with Physics or engineering background. It is generally separated into the theory and practical section, with theory lessons supporting the practical project.
The theory part contains the following topics: Electronic equipments, DC and AC power, PWM (Pulse width modulation) control, H-Bridge and Transistors, Kirchoff's Laws, Sequential logic and Arduino Programming. There will be a written exam at the end of term assessing understanding of above topics so revising is recommended.
The contents learned from above topics also have to be applied to program an electronic robot car to run on a designated track without error, built from scratch, for the practical project. The demo of robot car on the track will take a large portion of the final grade.
While contents are very basic, students with programming and/or Physics background will find it much easier to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is very professional and knows the content very well. He's also very enthusiastic, welcoming to questions and constantly invite students to approach him. Having said that, the contents taught in lectures are quite irrelavent to the project.
In contrast, the tutorials are not very useful as they only provide a guideline to your practical work in lab sessions, which can be easily read from the lab manuals. However, the tutorial session before project demo is very useful and worth attending as it provide tips to score well and dealing with problems in the project demo.
reviews.comment_grading:
20% from lab mid-term, assessing practical skills with electronic components.
20% from written exam, assessing theory knowledge from lectures.
20% from lab assignments, 30% from project demo and report. As project has to be worked in lab, lab attendance is strongly recommended for good grades.
10% from iPRS questions in lecture.
Groups can join the mini-contest if they score 20/25 in project demo, and by winning it you're guranteed A. Competition is tough, do not expect to win easily.
reviews.comment_workload:
The theory part is not difficult for students with Physics or electronics background, so not too much studying is needed.
The project however takes long time and hard work to fine tune the car to ensure it could perform well in the project, therefore the workload is quite high.

reviews.author: kckc
reviews.title: Hard work pays off !
reviews.comment_content:
A project oriented course. It teaches all the knowledge you need to have in order to build and program an autonomous vehicle and also the theories behind, including basic electronics, PWM, transistors, sensors, KCL&KVL, logics, and arduino programming. The content overall isn't difficult but definitely not easy.

This course consists of lectures, labs, tutorials, group project, lab midterm, written exam and mini contest(optional). The hardware part of the vehicle is built during the labs, while the software part has to be done during free time. The written exam takes place near the end of semester.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Song is a good teacher. He explains the concepts clearly and thoroughly with his own notes. He also advises us on major selection and our future.

The tutorials are useless. The tutor introduces the content of the labs only. Go to the labs directly and skip all the tutorials is fine.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab midterm 20%
Written exam 20%
6 Lab assignments 20%
iPRS quiz during lectures 10% (almost all lectures have iprs)
Project demo 25%
Project report 5%

My grade:
Lab midterm 20/20 (similar to past paper given)
Written exam 87/100
6 Lab assignments 20/20 (must hand in during the lab)
iPRS quiz during lectures 10/10 (only best 70% counted)
Project demo 25/25
Project report 5/5

Total: 97.4%, A+

Many students aim at perfection and got very high marks, so you must work hard to get a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
As this is a 4 credit course, its workload is definitely heavier than normal 3 credit course. Although they don't take attendance, you must attend all labs and almost all lectures to get full mark in quiz and lab assignment. I spent 2-3 days in the lab to finish the project and spent another whole day to write the report.

All in all, the workload is a bit heavy but hard work pays off.

reviews.author: #001/BULBASAUR
reviews.title: The grading is not THAT good, but still fair
reviews.comment_content:
The content of the course includes elementary knowledge about electricity (simpler than the DSE Physics electromagnetism), simple circuitry-building, basic logics and programming. The lectures are concise and organized, which should be easy to follow.

You will be given plentiful time to finish your tasks in each lab session. Being careful enough, you should be able to complete the assignment fast.

The mid-term examinations only cover the first 3 items. Preparing for the exam should not be too stressful, and scoring high in the written exam should not be difficult.

The final project is about making a line-tracking car in a group of 2. It is quite an interesting activity, but the problem-solving part could be frustrating.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The lecture is quite good. Being said the course is easy, parts of the syllabus could still be unfamiliar to some people. Johnny emphasizes a lot more on the important stuff, and will give you a satisfactory answer should you have any questions.

The tutorials can be considered a briefing section for the next lab session. No pop-up quizzes during the tutorials, so attendance is optional.

The TAs are very patient and helpful. They do not mind helping you debug (given you have tried that yourself) and sometimes offer advice that makes your lab session or project easier.
reviews.comment_grading:
Written mid-term examination 20%
Lab mid-term examination: 15%
In-class pop-up quizzes: 6%
Lab attendances/assignments: 24%
Final Project: 35% (25% project demo, 5% interview, 5% report)

Overall Score: 92.8/100
Letter Grade: B+

B range is very achievable. However, if you want to fall within A range, you will have to score 95/100 or above in overall. The course focuses on elementary knowledge, making the A range a highly-contested area with narrow cut-off.
reviews.comment_workload:
The main sources of workload are lab sessions and the final project. If you have a decent labmate, you should be able to finish them in a reasonable time frame. However, most of the times your labmate would be pulling your legs if not freeriding. Be ready to finish the final project alone and fix the faults committed by the labmates.

For your reference, in my case my labmate almost never showed up during the project period. He also managed to fire a key component multiple times, forcing me to suspend working on the project.

reviews.author: masuki
reviews.title: Not really that good grade
reviews.comment_content:
Although it is an introductory course for electronic engineering, the stuff they teach is a little bit daunting for students who have not studied physics in high school, mostly when they introduce electronic circuits and logic gates.

-Energy & Power
- DC Sources
- Pulse Generation
- PWM Control
- Transistor & Diode
- H-bridge
- Sensors
- Logics
- K-map
- Sequential Logics
- Programming Language, Part (I): Variables
- Programming Language, Part (II): Stucture
- Programming Language, Part (III): Functions
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Shen has explained the concepts of the course fairly clearly. He speaks at a fast pace, so you have to be quite attentive to keep track of what he is saying.
reviews.comment_grading:
20% Written Midterm
15% Lab Midterm
6% Pop-up Quizzes in lectures
24% Lab Assignments
25% Project Demo
5% Arduino Code Review
5% Project Report

Overall I got 75.8%, receiving a C+ grade. A friend of mine got 90%, yet he only received a B+. So is it really a "good grade course" as it seems? You decide.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload greatly depends on your labmate, as you have to finish building an electric car to get a full mark on the project demo. If you have a good labmate to carry you, the workload of this course is very light. However, if your labmate relies on you the entire time, then congratulations, good luck.

reviews.author: gearlessjoe
reviews.title: Fun course
reviews.comment_content: The aim of the course is for your group (groups of 2) to design a robot car that can follow a white track by itself. First part of the course teaches the concepts behind the robot car, such as electricity, PWM signals used to control the motor speed and logic (NOT, AND, OR etc.). Second part of the course briefly introduces programming with the Arduino Nano to implement logic on your robot car. After learning all this you are expected to build on the concepts used
reviews.comment_teaching: Johnny mostly reads off the powerpoints, not that interesting but also expected from most professors. There are TAs during the lab to help you with any problems you may encounter.
reviews.comment_grading:
- 1 written exam (20%)
○ 3rd Nov (Sat), 10:10 — 11:50 at LT-B and LT-C
- A few pop-up in-class quizzes (open book) (6% total)
- 1 lab midterm (15%)
○ Week 8-9, during regular labs
- 6 labs (4% each, 24% total) — minimum 4 labs attendance
- Final project (35%)
○ Project demo (25%)
○ Arduino code interview (5%)
○ Project report (5%)
There is no final exam, only midterms. This means that only content taught before the midterms will be tested, which is very good. There may be one or two quizzes after the midterm but those are open book so that is not really a problem.

There is also a contest for those that achieve a good score in the final project demo. The winners of that contest are guaranteed an A.
reviews.comment_workload:
Overall, workload is ok. There are two 50 minute lectures, one 50 minute tutorial and one 3 hour lab session per week.
The lectures are not necessary to attend (no attendance) but I find it helpful to have someone explain the content on the powerpoint.
The tutorial is also not necessary to attend, it mostly gives you more information on the upcoming labs.
If your group finishes the labs fast you can leave early.
For the final project, it mainly depends on how efficient your group works to finish the task. I have heard of some groups staying overnight in the lab to finish their car but I think that is unnecessary.

reviews.author: FireSplash68
reviews.title: SURVIVAL TIPS
reviews.comment_content:
Starts off with basic electronic physics like current, voltage. (If you took physics dses, the first part should be pretty smooth). Then it moves on to more complicated electronic components like H-Bridges, Transistors, etc.

The main objective of the course is to make a functional car using electronic junk to move in a given circuit.

They don't take attendance in lectures, but they do in labs. The course is highly focused on practical work, so you can skip lectures and read online notes. Lab attendance is more important.

BUT, they have quizzes in lectures that aren't announced. (3 quizzes in total, from my experience) It's good to be well informed about them by people in your own lecture or in other lectures. If you skipped a lecture that had a quiz, you could go to the next lecture available in the week to take it.
reviews.comment_teaching:
In all honesty, I've barely attended any lectures. Ive only attended like 2 or 3, cuz it mainly online.

But from what ive heard a lot from, prof song is a really interactive teacher. He likes to tell jokes and makes the lessons pretty entertaining. There are a couple of dull times tho, but what is a lecture without some, right? Overall, great instructor.

ZERO Tutorials attended. lol.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is fair, but not generous. (I don't know the exact percentages, refer to other reviews, soz :p)

This course has labs, a midterm and a project, BUT NO EXAM. (yay?)

Labs take up a moderate chunk of the percentage, but if you go to them regularly and know what youre doing, it's gonna be easy. You can always ask STAs / TAs for help during lab. If you finish early, you get bonus marks to your lab. Make sure you print out the labs before going to the room. (there are printers on the way to the lab, so you can print right before then) [I attended every lab, and got good marks in every one. I got the time bonus in the beginning of the course, but didnt in the ones later cuz the content got harder]

Midterms also take up a large amount of the percentage, there is lab and written mids.

DO NOT UNDERESTIMATE THE DIFFICULTY OF WRITTEN MIDTERMS. Many people's grades got screwed over cuz of midterms. If you want to survive midterms, there is a pastpaper example in canvas' files. The sample is very similar to the midterms, so try to go through that and absorb it with every fiber of your soul. The other tutorial notes are kinda good too. [I got pretty good marks in midterms thanks to the sample paper]

LAB MIDTERMS ARE PRETTY STRAIGHT FORWARD. It's very similar to the labs you'll do, just remember how all the components and equipment in the lab work and you should be ok. Bring a calculator (cuz i forgot mine) and pen/ pencil.

The Project is a nightmare if you dont know what youre doing, and it takes up a lot of your grading. (More elaborated in WORKLOAD)

Got an A- overall
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload isnt that much in the beginning, just labs (and maybe some pop quizzes) and done, but it will become a hella lot harder later on cuz the content becomes a bit harder and mainly cuz of the PROJECT.

Tips for the project
- Get a good teammate to work with for labs, cuz lab partners are gonna be your project teammate (preferably a friend). If they're lazy/ dont know what theyre doing, you're gonna die (unless you can carry the team like a mule, TEAMWORK IS NEEDED). Collaborating with your partner doesnt always mean you both need to meet up at the same time slot. You both can work on it in the lab whenever you can. just make sure you know your roles.

- Try team up and communicate with other groups (The grading is absolute, so no bell curves like the dses. Multi group collaboration is beneficial for everyone.)

- Be organized (If your entire breadboard is messed up with random components, debugging will be hard. Once your labs are done, you can clear it up for the project)

- Check your components if they work and on how they work ( If the circuit is not working, you're not always wrong, some sections of the bread board dont work + some of the sensors are faulty)

- Keep on testing your electro-car and try finish early. (If you go for the earlier final demo, youll have 4 attempts to run the car in case any errors occur. going for the later one only gives you 2 attempts, which is bad. Have timeslots to work on your car whenever the lab is open)

- Understand the way the components work. (You can always google image the components and see what pins do what. Not doing so might cause your components to short circuit and could even break your breadboard)

- There are going to be some allnighters, guaranteed. So prep some caffeine up for it.

- AFTER THE PROJECT, YOU WILL BE INTERVIEWED ON HOW YOUR CAR WORKS. Make sure you know how the components work to make the car run as it does.

-glhf

Got full marks for the project.

reviews.author: Jack_Au
reviews.comment_content:
一開始會重溫返中學physics E&M d basic野，例如叫你計current, voltage.
之後就係d新concept：
#KVL
#KCL
#Truth table
#K map
#Logics
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Song 對教學好有熱誠，成日會send email同你詳細解釋返今日上堂d內容，有唔明都可以直接去佢office搵佢。每次做lab果陣，佢都會落黎幫手，見到有人唔識點做或者做錯左，會去提醒返佢地。
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading system:
lab 22% (total 7 labs)
quiz 8% (記住有pop up quiz,唔好走堂）
written midterm 20%
lab midterm 15%
final demo 25%
after final demo interview 5%
final report 5%

My grade:
lab 22/22
written midterm  85/100
lab midterm  10/15
final demo  20/25
after final demo interview 5/5
final report 5/5

###overall 86%  A-
reviews.comment_workload:
workload唔大，冇assignment，亦都冇野要攞返去做。
不過臨近final demo之前果兩三個禮拜，要做定心理準備，可能要晚晚系lab留到8-9點先走得。
####check 清楚佢俾你個底板有冇問題，可能一兩個窿唔通電而你又唔知，debug又要搞好耐.......

reviews.author: HKo
reviews.title: Interesting Course
reviews.comment_content:
1. Basic Electronic Components
2. Power Consumption and Delivery System
3. AC Power Sources and Rectifiers
4. DC Power Sources and Regulation
5. IC and Pulse Generation
6. PWM Motor Control
7. Transistor and Diode Circuits
8. Motor Control by Transistor and H-bridge
9. Kirchhoff’s Laws
10. Sensor
11. Binary Number and Logic Gates
12. Boolean Algebra and K-Map
13. K-Map and Adders
14. Multi-bit Adder and Comparator
15. Sequential Logics and RS Flip Flop
16. Timing Diagram and D-Flip Flop
17. Finite State Machine

The content is very interesting, basic, and useful in electronic engineering field.
Originally, it's very easy, and then gradually, the content is getting harder. However, it's very satisfactory to make sense of all the materials with a larger scope after finishing the whole semester.
p.s. I usually understand the concepts taught in lectures after finishing the weekly tutorial and lab.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The Professor's teaching is great! He always encourages us to raise questions, creating an aggressive learning atmosphere. With this atmosphere, it helps student understand the content efficiently, and it sometimes introduces us creative ideas.
Besides, the professor is  always patient with your questions. He is willing to teach you with various methods, in order to let you understand.
In short, Professor Ross is indeed a nice teacher!
reviews.comment_grading:
quiz1: 8/10
quiz2: 10/10
quiz3: 10/10
Lab Midterm: 10/15
Written Midterm: 95/100
Final Project: 25/25
Finally got an A.

If you get a perfect final project score, what really matters about your final grade is the Lab Midterm. There will be practice sessions a week before the lab midterm. I didn't attend that, and I made a really stupid mistake during the lab midterm. I'll recommend you attend and practice.
If you perform well in other tests including the final project, and won't make big mistake in lab midterm, I believe you'll get an A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
I stayed up whole week for the final project. Although it's extremely satisfactory to see the result, I really don't like the week filled with frustration lol.
One will indeed learn a lot about debugging when conducting the final project. Moreover, one will also learn about the essence of persistence. :)

reviews.author: B.C.
reviews.title: You learn most not by studying, but by making
reviews.comment_content:
Content builds on high school physics, and gives a neat introduction into concepts in electronics; in my opinion it is useful even if you are not required to take it. On top of all of these, this course is more practical-based, as Prof. Song put it: "Here, labs are more important than lectures; don't skip labs even if you skip lectures."

The Project Period in the latter part of the course gives you the freedom to design your very own logic to instruct a robotic car to complete a route (e.g. staying on track, choosing the correct branch to go, bouncing off at goal). For me it is the part of the course "you can learn most" because you are doing everything on your own. The lab opens 24h except when having labs for other courses, and the teaching team would help you with everything you need including consulting about your design. It requires textbook concepts, practical skills, debugging skills, teamwork, creativity; if not trains them.

Lectures/Tutorials/Labs:
- Energy, Power
- Basic components [lab: basic equipment]
- AC sources [lab], DC Regulation [lab]
- Pulse generation, PWM control [lab]
- Transistor [lab] & Diode & H-bridge
- KVL, KCL -------- Written & Lab midterms up to here
- Sensor [lab]
- Logic [lab], K-map, Adders
- Combinational logic, Sequential logic, D-Flip Flop
- Finite State Machine
* Tutorial prepares you for lab work with a practical insight into the lecture textbook knowledge, each lab has a tutorial beforehand

Partnering:
Starting from lab 3 all the way to lab 7 and the whole project, you will partner with someone and work in a group of 2.
You can choose your own partner and declare that together on Canvas.
If you do not yet have one by the start of lab 3, you will be matched with one.

For fun:
Mini-Content
- This is not required by the course but you can win prizes (from USB memory sticks to a quadcopter)
- This time you need to do a U-turn and complete the track from start to end then from end back to start.
- Criteria:
    1. Distance
    2. Speed
    3. Elegancy: tidiness of the car appearance (breadboard)
    4. Simplicity: no. of logic gates used to achieve the effect
- For high aimers: don't bother to demolish everything and start over. We didn't do that and costed us a rather complex design in the end.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Song explained things super clearly and interestingly.
His approach to lecture is to write on the whiteboard (speedily), and he keeps everything simple and write as he speaks. He stresses on the point that being an engineer we are practical, so for example when doing some math he would skip the steps as long as everyone knows what's happening. Sometimes he uses the powerpoint for a slide or two but you can still see things link together. A very good presenter.

Before the start of lecture he usually plays some videos about recent robotics advancements, leaving behind inspiring remarks to let us imagine and think.

He makes jokes and tries his best to interact with his students too. Most of the students become friends with him. He would poke you to start a casual conversation. After lecture, he welcomes questions and we pretty much flocked to his room. Cantonese/Mandarin/English all okay. He tries to understand your level of understanding towards the concept and then interprets the concept from your perspective.

The last lecture was memorable. It was no longer about the course but more about coaching about university life and career, owing to the enrolment situation that most students here are freshmen. I can see that Prof. Song wanted to do more than transferring knowledge, but to make sense out of going to university as a norm, hence educate us to exploit our university life well.

TAs are nice also. Yimeng might have some issues with her English accents but she was kind and willing/passionate about teaching. Others assist lab operations as well as project period support well.

The teaching team was and probably will be generous enough to offer you support and even tell you not to worry in every possible ways. So just do your best, and have fun building!
reviews.comment_grading:
1. Exams: 35%
- Written Midterm: 20%
- Lab Midterm:15%
- There is no Final exams

2. Quizzes: 8%
Open book, no exact number of times, but having 3 is normal
For me the third quiz took place after midterms, so it was pretty much the only assessment on textbook knowledge after the midterms
Used to replace counting attendance in a way, as is usually conducted at the end of lecture time (enough to call your missing friends to come maybe)

3. Labs: 22%
- Lab 1-6: each 3%
- Lab 7 (final lab): 4%
- Bonus: each 3% if you and your partner can finish the lab in 2 hours
   (out of 2h50m), but only count towards this 22% (even if you have extra bonus points they would not count towards other breakdown parts like midterms)
* Attend a minimum of 4 labs to be eligible for Project Demo

4. Final Project: 35%
- Project Demo: 25%
     -> Separates into Early Demo or Final Demo which you as a group can sign up for. Early Demo would be around one week earlier but offers more chances for trials plus more time to demo. Recommended if your group can make it as you can lower risk of having sudden faults
    -> Safe measure is to videotape a run for backup. I heard that there must be some devastating malfunctions happening each semester which would ruin a few groups, sometimes it is the hardware problem and not even your design fault. You can get half (12.5%) maximum if you decide to use the video instead of demonstrating in extreme cases.
    -> Breakdown scores available for partial completion of various extents, so a perfect run can give you a full 25%
- Post Demo Interview: 5%
    (Conducted right after the demo, simple questions will be asked and both members of the group will have to answer. The purpose is to punish free-riders if found so if you understand what you have been working on, you are good to go)
- Project Report: 5%
    (Requires to mark contribution of each member, a 50%/50% would mean there's no free riders. The report should not exceed 6 pages, and to be handed in after the demo as the very last part of the course; instructions will be given but format is free)

------

Personally my partner and I received a satisfying A.
You and your partner score the same in most of the labs and project breakdowns.

My breakdown scores:
1. Written Midterm: 86/100, Lab Midterm: 10/15 (1/3 parts left blank)
2. Quiz 1: 10/10, Quiz 2: 7/10, Quiz 3: 9/10
3. Labs: all labs full marks (5/7 labs getting bonus)
4. Demo: 25/25, Interview: 5/5, Report 5/5
Overall percentage: 91.13%

I cannot comment on the grading distribution but to my knowledge Prof. Song is lenient enough to give out A-ranges, or at least he won't be harsh in grading.

Getting A+ maybe difficult. Prof. Song seemed to be planning to set a new rule in which if your group can give a perfect run in the Mini-Contest you can directly get A+ regardless of what. Whether this is true besides, you need substantial time and patience to achieve this (only 1 group did it in my term), so I can somehow predict that A+ is quite a grand quest.
reviews.comment_workload:
I would say it is moderate. Labs and project need most effort.

Lectures are short (50 mins) and not mandatory, Prof. Song had hand-written notes all scanned online, plus powerpoint slides uploaded frequently to Canvas. To be frank you can skip lectures and manage your own time to cram materials, though not much needed to cram anyways. Tutorials are similar, but they are more directly useful in terms of helping you to complete the lab work efficiently. Midterms are not particularly difficult in terms of content, you need to be calm and revise to the point of understanding is enough, no need to do much exercise, but be sure you are familiar with the lab machines as you rely on them in the lab midterm.

Labs and Project
- How much you can score in labs and project depend largely on your use of time. There were quite some instances where students get frustrated when they cannot finish the labs on time for the bonus or even before the lab session ends, for me it was the lab midterm; and getting desperate when they find out not much time is left for the Demo to come. It is unwise to lose scores because of this, so all I can say is be careful
- Your time invested is proportional to your performance. (Some say you would sleep in the lab in the project period...)
- Raise questions when you encounter problems, so the best way is to be attentive enough to be able to raise questions.

reviews.author: cindy2356458
reviews.comment_content:
It covers the basic electroc engineering principle and techniques.
After this course, student will apply the knowledge and principles learnt to design and build a functional robot by themselves.
If you like to build up any things by yourself, it will quite fun and interesting.
reviews.comment_teaching: The tutorial is good. Tutor will try her best to let us understand all the principle of this robot making by logic. If you have any problems, just ask the tutor or TAs bravely.
reviews.comment_grading: I only got C in this course as I got worse in written and labs midterm and pop up quizzes. I hadn't study the additional exercise and the labs very well before the midterm. It lead a worse results. Therefore, if you are not good at Elec, just try you best to understand the summary of this course before the midterm.
reviews.comment_workload:

Written midterm 20%
Lab midterm 15%
2 pop up in class quizzes (open book) 8%
7 assignments (22% in total, first 6labs 3% each, final lab 4%)
Final project 35%

Workload is fine, if you have all the lessons and try your best to get revision on this course.

reviews.author: cSophia
reviews.title: Interesting Content and Good Grading
reviews.comment_content:
Basic electronics.

The course consists of 20 lectures, 10 tutorials, and 7 labs. It talked about high-school physics, diodes, transistors, PWM control, KCL & KVL before midterm, and sensor, logic gate, K-map, logic design after midterm. The content is not very difficult, but you can go deeper if you are interested.

I think the amount and level of the content are quite appropriate for an introductory course.  However, most of the content are not necessary for the final project.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Fine.
Clear notes are released before class. In fact, you don't need to go to lecture and tutorial with the notes.
Instructor and tutor are quite helpful.
Fan is from mainland and we can ask questions in Putonghua:)
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair grading.

22% Labs (7 times)
8% Pop quizzes (3 or 4 times)
20% Written midterm
15% Lab midterm
27% Project
3% Interview
5% Report

It's easy to get full marks in labs and in-class quizzes. Many of my friends also got full marks in written midterm, but I think the calculation was a little difficult.
Lab exam was challenging. Many didn't have enough time to finish all three questions. You need to be very familiar with diodes, resistors, wire connection, and the equipment.
The project required much effort but it's not so hard to achieve perfect run as long as you have prepared for it.

Getting A+ with 96% overall. My friend gets A with 92% overall mark.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not that heavy for a four-credit course.

No assignment, but it's better to go through the guidance before labs.

Workload became bigger during the project period. My teammate and I each spent about 15 hours in the lab. The report cost us 10 hours. It's a good idea to start early.

reviews.author: Ching00000
reviews.comment_content: KCL, KVL, H-bridge, sensor, Arduino(C++), logic control, DC regulation...
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Murch is amiable, always extending a warm and welcoming demeanor to students. Moreover, he readily engages with their queries, demonstrating a genuine willingness to help and provide insightful explanations, making even the most intricate topics seem comprehensible.

Dr. Tang is responsive when it comes to emails. Her sense of responsibility, knowing they can rely on her for prompt and helpful replies. Additionally, her classes are meticulously prepared, ensuring a productive and enriching learning environment that leaves no room for ambiguity.

When it comes to Teaching Assistants (TAs), there is a mix of personalities and approaches. On one hand, some TAs stand out for their unwavering support and approachability, eagerly assisting students in understanding course materials and offering valuable guidance.

On the other hand, there are a few TAs who appear less inclined to respond to students' inquiries. This reluctance to answer questions can be frustrating for some students who seek clarification or additional assistance.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab: 30% of the final grade.

Quiz: 10% (full marks obtained by scoring 60% on Q20).

Lab Exam: 15%.

Written Exam: 20%.

Project: 20% (Various sessions are conducted to test the reboot car).

Report: 5%.

*Everyone performed exceptionally well in this course, so even if you received high marks, the overall grade might not be significantly inflated.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quiz: Quizzes are used to take attendance and are administered in almost every lesson, consisting of only two simple questions.

Lab: Labs are conducted every week and are quite easy if you prepare beforehand for the lab session.

Written Exam: The written exam includes practice sessions and Q&A sessions facilitated by the TAs.

Project: The project requires approximately 3-4 weeks to complete and is done in collaboration with groupmates.

Report: The report should be around 1500 words in length.

==> The tasks are quite straightforward, but there is an amount of work.

reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Policy

Lab: 6 Lab Assignments (30% total).
Quiz: Pop-up In-class Quizzes (open book, 10% total), online submission in iPRS (20 questions in total, only the top 60% answers will be counted).
Exam: Lab Exam (close book, 15%) and Written Exam (close book, 20%).
Project: Project Demo (20%) and Report (5%).

If you want to get A range. You must be extremely careful in Lab exam and written exam.
I got full in Lab, quiz and project. Above mean with around 1 SD in written exam. But I made some careless mistakes in Lab Exam. So I get the mean score.
Unfortunately, I only end up with B+ in this course. It is very disappointed.
reviews.comment_workload: Not as much as a 4 credit course. Only need to read the guidelines to prepare for the lab before the lesson. In the middle of the semester, it is close to the project period and no lecture, lab and tutorial need to attend. So that you have more time to do revision of other course. It is very good.

reviews.author: alvfan
reviews.title: easy course testing your carefulness
reviews.comment_content:
basic circuit components: H-bridge, invertor, NPN/PNP transistor. Robot car project using Arduino programming (Similar syntax to C++).

Easy content so this course is competitive. Most students can get full marks in in-class pop-up quizzes, labs & project. The two mid-terms (lab & written) decide your grade. You need to be EXTREMELY CAREFUL in midterms as there is no room to make careless mistakes.

6 Labs and project demos: A GOOD TEAMMATE IS IMPORTANT. You need to complete all lab tasks within 2hrs to get full marks.

Lab exam: Be an active learner in labs then you can perform well in lab exam.
Written exam: Make sure you understand how the NPN transistor works.
My advice: install simultaneous linear equations in 3 unknowns program into your calculator to double-check your calculation in KCL/KVL.
reviews.comment_teaching: Easy content so lectures are boring. Sometimes I cannot understand what TAs is saying because of the English accent. But All TAs are willing to help you in labs and answer my questions (especially TANG, Yimeng, such a kind TA)
reviews.comment_grading:
In-class Quizzes: 10%
Labs: 30%
Mid-terms: 15%, 20% (Lab & Written)
Project: 20%, 5% (Demo & Report)

Lab exam:
mean: 11.87
SD: 3.03

Written exam:
mean: 65.69
SD: 22.57

My score:
lab exam: 15/15
written exam: 95/100
Overall: 99/100 (A+)

Easy course, competitive grade. You need an overall 95+ to get an A range.
reviews.comment_workload:
the workload is just two midterms. Try to aim for full marks if you want an A range.

the workload also depends on your teammate. You need to complete all lab tasks within 2 hrs to get full marks. Time is tight if you need to carry your teammate. I had a good teammate so our group managed to perform tasks on time but I can see half of the groups have trouble finishing tasks within 2 hrs. You better have a look at the lab documents before labs.

FIND A GOOD TEAMMATE AND BE PREPARED FOR MIDTERMS!!

Yea, that's C+, which I initially predicted as B or B-.

RIDICULOUS.

Think twice if you're taking it because it's an INTRODUCTORY COURSE, don't be too naive and take it as a foolish Year 1 kid if you want to pursue a leng grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
First thing first, you had to self-study all things for all concepts and do more practice for the written exam.

You are strongly suggested to have good time management in the lab, as a late complement would cause a deduction in your 1 "bonus mark".

Moreover, the project and the lab are carried out with your teammate and their attitude and performance could vary.

For example, my teammate is a kind Korean exchange student, she's pretty good at doing lab and writing codes.
But when she is absent and travelling in Korea while I have the last lab, I'm totally fucked and I can't do it on time (I had to do the work all by myself, which was supposed to be done by the whole TEAM).

And I even have to build the whole car all by myself and reconstructed it several times. Get prepared for having several trails and discussions and debugging, which would be demanding and testing your patience luck.

However, if you got a good teammate, your workload would be surprisingly light. So please do bring one or two reliable friends to reg this course.

As a 4-credit course, the course is way too heavy.

reviews.author: 汤圆戳不破
reviews.comment_content:
Contents involve transistors, diodes, also involves KCL and KVL calculation, H-bridge, resistors, and some basic ICs.In the course, they will teach Arduino and some basic C++ for final project.

The final project involves building a robot car that follows a white line on a black mat controlled by the arduino nano board.

Just having the knowledge of high school physics is enough to handle the course materials.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is quite good. The instructor explained the materials by giving explicit examples and the logics are straightforward. All the teaching team including TAs are willing to help. They help a lot in the final project. However, I would say that I find TAs are more helpful than just attending the lectures since sometimes the instructor may not notice that he is going a bit fast.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is pretty good for me. Note that it can be pretty competitive though.

Policy:
Lab 30% (6 Labs in total)
Pop-up Quiz 10% (total 20, only top 60% answers will be recorded)
Lab Exam 15% (around October)
Written Exam 20% (around November)
Project Demo 20% (you get 2 trials, each trial allows you to submit 2 versions of code and 2 attempts per code)
Report 5%

Overall lab: 30/30
Overall Quiz: 10/10
Lab Exam: 15/15, (μ=12.37, σ=3.02)
Written Exam: 97/100 (μ=71.18, σ=19.86)
Demo: 20/20
Report: 5/5
Final Letter Grade: A+ (just for reference)

Well the grading is not that good to some extent because I know one of my friends whose overall was around 94, and he only gets B+...
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is small.

You basically just need to attend lectures because of the pop-up quiz, tutorials for details about the lab, and lab for the lab score. However, since the course is not hard, there is no need for you to review after class. The project can be overwhelming if the car doesn't work, so make sure you enter every test session to make sure your car runs well.

Quiz are mc and will be done during lecture so you have to attend lectures if you don't want to miss them. But you only need to get 60% of the mcs right get full 10%.

QUIZ: 10%
EXAM: 35%(Lab Exam, 15%, Written Exam, 20%)
PROJECT: 25%(Demo, 20%, Report, 5%)

Workload consists of lab work and final project. No HW.
One lab session each week, takes about 2hrs on average. You can ask the tutors for help during them.

Final project takes time, but can be finished in less than a week.  You can also ask tutors for help during code testing sessions.
