reviews.author: FrostyP4nc4kes
reviews.title: Best Year 1 Engineering Course out there
reviews.comment_content:
The whole course is based on making a robotic car that can traverse a track.

You will learn about different circuit components(at a very very basic level)

Topics that will prepare you for the final project would be
- Circuit components(Resistors, capacitors, diodes, and transistors)
- Kirchoffs Voltage and Current Laws, which are pretty much just conservation of energy laws for circuits
- car components(motors & pulse width modulation,  sensors, Arduino, H-bridge and inverter Integrated circuits at a basic level)
- Boolean logic, algebra, De Morgans law (no k map which is disappointing and I highly recommend self studying
- combinational logic(which uses the very basic logic gates)
- coding in C/C++

Over all, this course is so fun.

The labs are a bit hard at first, but once you get used to the equipment and basic design thinking, its relatively easy to complete each lab in under 2 hours.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Shen is a really good teacher. I like his dumb humour when explaining different components and concepts. Honestly I don't see any problem with his teaching! I dropped by one of Qiao Shiming's lectures, and he spoke like a robot, so err yeah I don't recommend Qiao Shiming. Prof Ki is also a good teacher, also good humour too, but I'd still say that I'd recommend Profession Shen as first choice of teacher tho.
reviews.comment_grading:
Since the course is quite basic, the means in the examinations are quite high.

- In class quizzes: 10% just attend class, they're freebies.(most can get full)
- Lab exercises 6 in total: 30%(most can get full)
- Lab Exam: 15%, can be trippy! make sure you know ur machinery!(Mean 12/15)
- Midterm Exam that is basically a final exam(and in my opinion a bit too difficult):
20% (Mean 71.18/100)
- final project and written report: 25% Most people can get full.

sadly with the means being high, its hard to know where the A range cutoff is. Also don't expect an A+ when you get mid 90s ;-;

Edit: dont even expect A in mid 90s... terrible grading
reviews.comment_workload:
Very low for 4 credits! NO ASSIGNMENTS WHATSOEVER! The project was tough and took a considerable amount of time. I'm warning you now, the hardware is shite, the logic can be very difficult if you're new to programming. So don't slack, and get it done asap!

Also, for labs, they have a stupid 2 hours or under bonus mark that isn't really a bonus mark, but more of a 'if you don't finish in 2 hours you get -1. But the TAs are very forgiving :) so you can probably get 30/30 even if you don't complete everything in time(speaking from experience xd)

reviews.author: Frank22
reviews.comment_content: Mainly talking about: transistors, KCL&KVL, PWM, truth map, K-Map, and logic.
reviews.comment_teaching: There are lectures, tutorials, and lab sessions every week. The tutorial is a significant way to digest what you've learned so far during class and also get some extra notes about the topics. Also, it's pretty beneficial as it helps you prepare for the upcoming lab assignments.
reviews.comment_grading: There are in-class quizzes in the lecture sessions which account for about 8%. They will be held without notice so it's best to show up for the lectures. There's also the Lab work which accounts for about 22%, a written AND lab midterm which accounts for 20% and 15% respectively, and finally the demo which holds 30% of the final grade along with a report which is 5%.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload starts to get rather heavy after lab 7/8, where you and your lab partner need to design and work on the logic for the robot. The amount of debugging that you might need to do depends on the overall complexity and also how well you've designed the logic.

reviews.author: yhanbai

reviews.comment_grading: As mentioned, many hand-on labs were made to be done online. I made a mistake on the  circuts problem, and got a -20. completely abnormal grading system. Final grade is B.
reviews.comment_workload: light workload definitely.

reviews.author: youyo
reviews.title: good grading
reviews.comment_content:
The teaching materials are just brief concept about electric circuits. For anybody who have learnt high school physics it is just easy peazy lemon squeezy.

01 Introduction

05 Pulse Generation

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Shao comes from mainland China so don't expect his English to be as fluent as native speakers. But I don't think his accent is as severe as to be unintelligible, you will definitely understand what he is saying (Actually the lecture materials is not that important, you can easily find similar things on the Internet if the accent really bothers you). Other than that, Prof. Shao is very nice. He answers everyone's question in the lecture with patience.

TA is very very kind in this course, they will answer almost everything if you emailed them. And I strongly suggested you to email them frequently.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grading (!!!but varies in the final project!!!)
!!!If the lesson is conducted online, just ignore this part.!!!

In-class IPRS quesitions 10%
Lab reports 30%
Mid-term 35%
Final project 20%
Final project report 5%

All of these components are pretty easy to get full score as long as  you pay attention to the lectures or you learn the material after class. For the IPRS questions, it is conducted in class and only the   top 70% are calculated. It is very simple to full score. Same for the lab reports and final report, you will get  full score with little effort. The only two tricky parts for this course are mid-term and final project.  If your car cannot complete the run, say it veered off route
at the second corner, you will only get around 14/20. In other courses, it may just be the difference of one subgrade. But in this course, it will be the matter of a whole grade, A+ to B+!!!

But, there's time for you to adjust your final project on the real examination route before real exam. If you spend enough time there shouldn't be any problem on getting full score. ( And there's four trials, every trial counts. You can gamble on your luck)

I finally got an A for this course. 96/100.
I lost 3 marks in the mid-term and 1 mark in the lab report all due to some extremely silly mistakes. I will rate the grading as good because of the simple content. On the other hand, simple means severe competition. That‘s why opinions differ for grading in this course
reviews.comment_workload: The workload basically depends on the final project. If  do will in the final project, e.g. fine sensors and motors, and the car runs as expected, the workload is basically lecture and tutorial time you spent. But if your final project is completely chaos, you will have quite a difficult final period😅.

Titles of the slides:

02 Components
03 Energy
04 KCL KVL Part I
05 KCL KVL Part II
06 DC Power Source
07 Transistor
08 H Bridge
09 DC Motors
10 PWM control

In my opinion, I kind of hope that I can have more quiz or assignments in this course because most of the content is not test on the Final exam, and I will probably forget what I have learnt in this course after a few weeks.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lecture: The course is taught at a manageable pace. Good
Tutorial: It basically teach you how to work on your Lab + a little recap of lecture materials.
Lab: TA will tell you which part of your circuit goes wrong and you can keep adjust it.
Things are easy to catch up, understandable and not confusing.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading:
Lab Assignments (30%)
IPRS (10%) (20 questions in total, only the top 60% answers will be counted)
Final exam (35%)
Project (25%)

It is insanely easy to get full marks on lab asm and IPRS.
Final is easy so try not to make mistakes.
Project is a bit complex to explain, there are peoples who buy code in goop (Cheating) to get full marks. Therefore, as an average student with basic moral standards, you need to be careful on testing your codes in demo in order to compete with those cheaters.

Lab:30/30
Quiz:10/10
Exam:87/100
Project Demo:18/20
Project Report:5/5
Total: 93.45%
Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light as a 4 credit course. Probably because it is conduct in online this year. In the project, we don't have to build cars but only need to work on the coding.
The only homework is the lab which I spend around 2 hours or less in each week.
Also, there are not much things needed to prepare the exam. Only have two additional exercise which takes less than 1 hour each. And it is already enough for preparing the exam.

reviews.author: leontang
reviews.comment_content: basic knowledge about electricity, logic, programming
reviews.comment_teaching: The first few lesson I felt hard to follow as I couldn't clearly listen what was Professor Vinod saying. However, after 2-3 lesson, Professor slowed down his talking speed and I used to that. I found he explain very clearly and was very easy to follow.
reviews.comment_grading:
This course was so easy so the average score are quite high. About 15% were in class quiz. Student are required to answer a simple question to get the mark of that lecture. Only the top 70% of your quiz will be counted, so it should be easy to get all 15% mark.

There are some lab session, you just need to follow the guild line of each labs and you can get the mark for those lab. Also, there is a worksheet which you have to finish in each lab, but most of them you only need to answer the value you get in the lab session, so they are quite easy.

There is only a mid term but no final. So the exam was held quite early. The content of the exam are nearly the same as past paper. It is quite easy to get high mark if you are willing to do some revision.

The last grading part was a assignment, just enjoy crafting the robot and doing coding to let it run. This is the best part of this course so you may want to have a face to face class instead of online class
reviews.comment_workload: extremely low workload, no homework at all, only one assignment and it can be finished within a few hours if you are good enough

reviews.author: Angez
reviews.comment_content:
Very easy. Even middle school students can handle it. (I'm not kidding)

Just some very basic electrical knowledge. There are some scary-sounding names like KCL and KVL, but surprisingly simple.

It does require some programming, but it's still easy. My only programming background is the "turtle" thing, even not Python turtle, and that's enough to program the control logic of a robot car.  

I didn't have any C++ background, and even didn't do any self-learning. I just simply imitated the sample code given by prof and achieved Perfect Run with "if/else" conditional statements.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher has a mainland accent, which is just what I look forward to, because it's not easy for me to understand native English.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very good. The exam questions are so easy that I thought I had to get full marks to get  A+, but in fact, several mistakes are okay.

The reason I say "easy" is because the types of questions in the exam are very similar to those in the Past Papers. If you study hard, you'll do well (get nearly full marks).

Overall above 98% are very likely to get A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Almost no workload, you have enough time to make the robot car in the lab class, hardly need to take up any extra time. There are several attempts, but as long as you reach Perfect Run in the first time, you can finish the course in advance, concentrating on other courses.

There will be pop-up quizzes in every class, but it's not difficult. The teacher almost tells you the answers.

reviews.author: Venus Cloud
reviews.title: An ordinary introduction course
reviews.comment_content: The lectures cover the content of circuit building and coding. As for circuits, it provides a shallow glimpse, which is applied in exams and labs. Further physical principles behind circuit components are not discussed in this course. Some C++ coding is taught in the last few lectures. After that, students need to apply this to design programs for their robot cars.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I guess my professor is good but not at teaching.
For tutorials, IA Dr. Tang explains things clearly and specifically, which is helpful in the following labs.
reviews.comment_grading:
I got 97.75 out of 100 in total scores and got an A. The missing scores are caused by one and a half MCs in the online exam. It is said that only students with scores above 98 can get A+ this semester.
P.S.: My exam score is 92.5 (Mean: 70.66, SD: 21.29) and I get full marks in the rest assessment.
reviews.comment_workload:
No assignments outside labs (^_^)/
No final exam (^_^)/
The final project may be time-consuming, so plan ahead with your groupmate.

reviews.author: Fido
reviews.title: Insane grading
reviews.comment_content: The first few lectures of the course are similar to what we were taught in high school physics, basically some calculation and concepts about electric circuit, voltage and current. In the later part , some more new concepts are introduced such as KCL and KVL, transistors and PWM control, but overall it should be easy to follow and is quite fun to learn about.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is a cool dude, although his Indian accent could be difficult to follow.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was insane, like really really insane. According to other comment , it seems like u would need a overall of 96% in  order to get to A range, which means that the margin of error is basically zero, on top of that, the project was kinda a RNG, the same set of codes can produce drastically different result anytime. Use myself as an example, we have been through tons and tons of hardware issue like the the fuse was burnt out, the screw were not tightened and the wheels not being in sync, which already put us in a giant disadvantage. The fun doesn't stop there, during the final session, the luck wasn't on our side, by an inch of nail, we went from potentially getting 18/20 to just 14/20.

Back to the grading, it was insane. I was above mean in the final, with all other stuff except the project getting near full marks, with the 14/20 in the project, it makes to about 88% in the overall course mark. Guess what, it only gets me a B-, not even B+ by nearly 90%, but B-, it was insane!!!!!!!!!
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was light at the early part of the semester as there was no assignment , one thing to be mentioned tough is that there would be a lab every week, dealing with the component and the circuit could be time -consuming and frustrating at times, but if you are into those stuff, you might find that interesting. However, it was intense at the end of the semester , you are required to finish a coding project , which takes up a majority of your time. We were allowed to test our codes every day , building your code is already not a easy job, the major issue tough is that only 3 project mats are provided every testing session, so we basically have to wait for eternity in order to go through one trial, as a result, all our times were taken up to the point that we even have to skip other lectures to deal with the project.

reviews.author: ZzZzZ
reviews.title: Not difficult
reviews.comment_content: Some basic knowledge about physics and electronics. And the final project is about building a robot car. The contents cover many aspects but each of them is not deep, and all of them are easy to understand. If someone learned physics in high school, the contents of this course are a piece of cake, I think.
reviews.comment_teaching: As the contents are easy, it's hard to say whether the teaching is good. But my professor, SHAO, is a quite good one. He is always patient and approaching. TAs are also great. They helped me a lot in labs and the final project.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab 30%
quiz 15%
online exam 30%
final project 25%
To be honest, It's not that good grading. As the contents are easy, you have to face a fierce competitiion. And even a very little mistake will reduce you to a lower grade.
reviews.comment_workload: There are no assignments, so the workload is light before the final period. But the final project takes a lot of time. You have to spend many time adjusting your code, doing demo, communicating with your lab partner. But overall, the workload is not that heavy.

reviews.comment_content:
- Basic Components
- Energy & Power
- DC Sources
- Pulse Generation
- PWM Control
- Transistor
- H-bridge
- KCL & KVL
- Sensor
- Logics
- K-map
- Exam Review
- MCU & Arduino
- Arduino Code (I): Functions
- Arduino Code (II): Variables & Structure
- Arduino Code (III): Conditional Statement
- Final Project

An interesting introductory course to EE, you can learn about electronic circuits and a little bit of programming.

Lectures: Attendance is compulsory because there is an iPRS quiz (2 questions) almost every lesson, but most of them are very straightforward. Read the slides before the lectures and you should be good to go.

Tutorials: Focused on preparing us for the next lab. Didn't attend most of them but the slides are useful enough.

Midterm(online, on canvas): Additional exercises and past paper with solutions are provided for midterm preparation. The exam itself is not hard, questions similar to the past paper provided. One minor issue is that you can't return to the last question after you have completed a question (i.e. can't skip questions). This could be somewhat painful especially when doing MCQs.  

Lab: 2 in a group. The tasks aren't too difficult, just remember to read the lab instructions beforehand and refer to the tutorial slides for breadboard arrangements.

Project: Build a line following car. Same groupmate as the lab sessions. There are early and final demo for grading (4 trials each demo), only the trial with the highest mark will be counted. 18/20 for a perfect run, 20/20 only if the perfect run is achieved within 25 seconds. The base logic of the car is quite simple, but expect to handle a lot of edge cases when testing your car on the actual track. A project report (>1200 words) should be submitted after the final demo.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is generally a nice person and tries to make his lessons interesting, although with a heavy accent. He also gives us hints before each quiz.
Don't know much about the TA; I didn't attend most of her tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab: 6 Lab Assignments (30% total).
Quiz: Pop-up In-class Quizzes (open book, 15% total), online submission in iPRS, only the top 70% of your performance will be counted.
Exam: On-line Exam (close book, 30%).
Project: Project Demo (20%) and report (5%).
reviews.comment_workload: Adequate, except for the project which could take a week or two to debug.

reviews.author: botbot
reviews.title: good course!
reviews.comment_content: Teach some basic electronic concepts and components such as calculate the Voltage and Current, AC and DC electronic circuits, operational amplifiers and diodes, binary numbers etc. These kinds of concepts are not really difficult. Year 1 students can easily handle it.
reviews.comment_teaching: Some quizzes make you should always attend the lesson. Quizzes are straightforward, I must say, Everyone, can get a full mark unless you are absent.
reviews.comment_grading: Not too bad. The mid-term exam is a way to distinguish between the a and b ranges. So even you get a bad result in the final model. you can also get a range.
reviews.comment_workload: Not really high. There is 1 lab we should do each week. We do the homework, make a pdf file and upload it to canvas; We also use the website called Tinkercad to make a circuit and demo to TA.

reviews.author: 一塊石頭
reviews.comment_content:
Including logic gate, KVL/KCL, C coding basic, some knowledges about the current, voltage, resistance, etc.

Not very difficult but still require times for me to understand it.

DSE Physics will help you some, but not many.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is acceptable but not very clear. Sometimes I have to watch some tutorials from the internet.
reviews.comment_grading:
You have do one labs like every weeks. These labs are quite easy to finish but you still need a hour to finish it. The tutorial will solve most of the difficulties, and you can finish it after some testing and modification.

The final are also acceptable. The questions are not hard to answer if you have do revision.

The pop-up quiz are annoying I would say. You have participate every lesson as you may miss these pop-up quiz if you absent for that lesson.

The car coding, which contain 35% marks, is a disaster. You can get extremely different result with same codes. My car move backward in the first time and run out of control quickly in the second time. Even the demo from the professors themselves requires three time to complete.

So, if you believe yourself as a lucky person, you are welcome to join such gambling. As a result, my report of this demo even have higher mark than my demo.
reviews.comment_workload:
Every week you need to participate the course if it is possible to have a pop-up quiz that day, and you need to finish the lab project.

You do not need to study for mid-term exam, but I would rather to have two exams than having over one-third of my grades determined by gambling.

If it is in real time online delivery mode, it is not recommended to choose this course. It will let you feel frustrated with you efforts paid into the course.

reviews.author: CUCOOPE
reviews.title: Not good for online lesson
reviews.comment_content: Includes things like resistance, voltage, current etc. Basically things in HKDSE physics related to electricity. It also includes new stuff about micro controller units and simple arduino programming
reviews.comment_teaching:
Overall speaking, the teaching is ok. But maybe it's because of the accent and the online teaching format, It is hard to fully understand the concept behind different micro controllers.

In my opinion, it is best to have some self study out of class time.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is terrible. DON'T TRUST THE B+ GRADING NIN UST SPACE!!!

Since the lecture is held on Zoom, the project that is part of the grading system is also held via Zoom. The project for me is to write   an Arduino program for a robot car they built in order for the car to follow the track. But because it's held via Zoom, there is NO CHANCE for you to look at the track and the car in person. There are only one chance for test run, which is obviously not enough for anyone to write a program. As a result, only a few students were able to complete the track--most of us failed. Many people got bad grades
reviews.comment_workload: There are no assignments, only labs that involves building circuits in Thinkercad following guides every week. It can be done in less than 10 minutes.

reviews.author: eb
reviews.comment_content: In the first half covers basic electronics and circuits, then focuses on Arduino. Quite difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching: I had Prof. Park who is a visiting professor from Korea. He's a very good professor and agreed to meet me when I had questions, he explained very patiently. However, his quizzes are very hard compared to other professors of the course.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite bad. 30% of your final grade is the project which is coding a line follower robot. However, they only let you try your code on the robot once before grading it. So most people failed as there was no way to test the code along the way.

The exam was also very difficult, with a section on building circuits on Tinkercad which was quite challenging. The fact that there is only one exam is quite stressful.

The labs are fine, just building circuits again.
reviews.comment_workload: Quite high. Labs every week and quizzes quite often too. You really have to organise your time well for this course.

reviews.author: Patricknely
reviews.title: Freshmen are not recommended to take this class
reviews.comment_content:
ELEC1100 is designed to provide the fundamental knowledge on the basic electrical engineering, components design and electrical circuit.

There are 20 classes in total, 18 of them talk about electrical engineering’s stuff, and the only last 2 of them talk about C++ programming. The structure of the class is POORLY organized, btw your final project ONLY needs to program with C++ since the physical robot-car has been built by TA.

Tutorials are very helpful, often provide answers to each week’s homework.
Due to online teaching, Labs use Tinkercad to construct circuits, which is a very educational website.

No mid-term, a final exam , and a final project ( A LOT OF PROGRAMMING IS NEEDED!!!!!! Aiming to let the robot car to follow the track and run all the way to the end)

I need to mention the details of the final project. Only ONE trial session is provided, you can only have TWO versions of your coding to check out your robot-car’s performance. REALLY BAD EXPERIENCE IN FINAL PROJECT.

Overall, the teaching material is actually well, however NOT HELPFUL for final project.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof has a little accent, a little bit difficult to figure out what he says.
ppt is quite organized.
reviews.comment_grading:
Although the experience of final project is not satisfying at all. The grades are actually NOT that bad.

Labs: 6 lab submissions (30%)

Quizs: 4 pop-up quizzes (open book, 15%, 3 out of 4 will be counted). (Very easy, questions are really fundamental)
PS,,, Don’t try to skip classes, the quizzes are planned to be tested at the end of the class, and prof won’t tell you if there’s a quiz or not.

Exam: (11 multiple choices questions, 1 calculation problem, 2 circuit designing questions) (30%)

Project:
Coding Project (20%)
Project Report (5%) 1000 words




I got:
Labs, Quizzes FULL MARKS
Final Exam:   92/100
Coding Project:   6/20
Project Report:  5/5

A-
reviews.comment_workload:
Not too much workload.
Be CAREFUL if you are not familiar with C++ programming, you need WAY TOO MANY TIME to prepare for your final project.

reviews.author: mickyli1117
reviews.comment_content: The content cover many areas including logic, Arduino, electronic stuff.
reviews.comment_teaching: Average, most of the notes are Powerpoint files. However, for some hand-written notes like calculation, graph etc. It is quite uncomfortable to see.
reviews.comment_grading:
Labs: 30%
Quiz: 15%
Exam: 30%
Project: 25%

There are 6 labs in total and they are pretty much free mark if you just stick with the notes that are provided.

There are 3/4 pop-up quizzes during the lecture, it's a bit difficult but worth spending time on since it can make a grade difference.

For the project, you need to program a source code for the robot car. It is almost impossible to get a high mark as you only can have 4 trials. Make sure you have done debugging before submission.
reviews.comment_workload:
Lab:
The lab is quite easy to do if you look at the instruction given, at the same time, it is good as you can practically learn the theory taught in the lecture.

Quiz:
Since there are quizzes during the lecture, you can't only do revision before the exam.

Project:
Not recommended to spend much time. As your code may be theoretically correct, but it may screw up for no reason during the project demo. I would say it's more about luck.

reviews.author: DrainGang
reviews.title: Do not take until f2f!
reviews.comment_content:
Basic electronic engineering, course separated into two halves, with the first half being electronic circuits (diodes, transistors and such), and the second half being Arudino programming.

Both were quite interesting, and were not very difficult as well especially if you have prior programming knowledge. The only difficult part of the course was KVL/KCL, and for that I suggest watching some youtube videos explaining them, in particular the video made by Organic Chemistry Tutor which explains it better than the lectures or the notes can.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching was decent, Professor Shen did have an accent but was overall clear in speaking and explained ideas well enough, the lecture powerpoints are detailed and explained course concepts clearly, lectures were a bit boring but were mandatory because of the in class pop-up quizzes.

Tutorials were simple and the TA just tells you what to do for the labs, Fox explained the labs and projects extremely well in the tutorials (the circuits for the labs are pretty much given to you completed, so you just recreate it in tinkercad...)

Labs were arranged very well with TAs checking your circuit, which takes only about 10 minutes of waiting and demoing only takes a minute.
reviews.comment_grading:
online exam: 30%
labs: 30%
quiz: 15%
project: 20%
project report: 5%

Online exam: held a few weeks after the middle of the semester, tests the entire syllabus. 3 parts, part 1 is 10 MCQs, part 2 is a long question based on KVL/KCL, part 3 is building a circuit in tinkercad. Acceptable difficulty, mean is around 69/100.

Labs: build a circuit following the tutorial and finish the lab report, very easy, most students can get full marks on this.

Quiz: 4 in lecture pop-up quizzes over iPRS, quiz area based on recent lectures, 10 questions, given 1-2 minutes for each question, very nerve wrecking as you cannot go back and the time is short.

Project: The worst part of the course, you make a robot car that tracks a line. You have only 4 attempts to test your code, so if you are unlucky, or are the type of person that needs to test your code, prepare to do very poorly.

Project report: 4 page report based on the project, including graphs, logic tables and such.

Got mean overall (68/100), therefore got a B-, expected according to UST standards. Again, the project process was a mess, therefore you shouldn't take this until f2f.
reviews.comment_workload:
Rated at a B because while workload is heavy, it's pretty good for a 4 credit course.

Popup quizzes: Mostly OK, study the notes a little bit before the quizzes and you will do fine (Very nerve-wrecking to be limited to 1-2 minutes per question though...)

Labs: almost no workload, recreate the circuit given to you in the tutorial in tinkercad, and finish the lab report which takes 30 minutes at most once per week.

Online exam: acceptable, the exam doesn't cover a lot of area since its held about a month after the midterms, split into 3 parts, MCQs which were quite difficult, a long question regarding KCL/KVL, and a circuit building question that just asks you to build a circuit in tinkercad.

Project: Hardest part and also the worst part of the course, you only have 2 chances to test your code, once during the test, and once during the FINAL demo, there is no other chance to test your code, which is absurd. Therefore in the end most people got less than 5/20 with only a few people getting more than half.

Project report: Just follow the guidelines given to you and it would be easy, but do make sure you fulfill ALL the requirements as listed in the guidelines.

reviews.author: enor2017
reviews.title: Not good for online, but grade is ok
reviews.comment_content: I've attached the schedule and topic below.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Shen Shaojie has a solid knowledge in this area, as you can find some introductions of him on web. His accent is relatively good, and as he speaks slowly, you can easily understand him. I think sometimes he doesn't know how to express himself, so there maybe some pauses, but it won't affect anything.

My TA is FOX, he seems strict but actually he is a very nice guy. He will respond to your emails very quick and explain things clearly to you. Also this sem, the final project was unable to hold f2f, but FOX has done everything he could to ensure a fair environment. Though I didn't get a satisfying mark in project, but I think he've done an excellent job.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
- 6 Labs, 6 * 5% = 30%
- 3 Quizzes, 3 * 5% = 15%
- 1 Written exam, 30%
- 1 Project, 20%
- 1 Project report, 5%

For labs, we did it on Tinkercad, which is easy to get used to. Each lab, they'll give you detail descriptions of what you're supposed to do and during Tutoiral lessons, FOX will explain more and even show you the correct circuit for your reference. You need to assemble your circult before lab lessons and during Lab lessons, you need to share screen and show your work to TA, and after demonstration, you need to submit a simple report, the skeleton has already done for you and you only need to put some screenshots inside. This part is easy to get full mark.(sometimes they don't give full mark for report, e.g. 0.95/1, but it doesn't matter)

For quizzes, it appears randomly in the last 10 minutes of a lecture, so you need to pay attention if you usually skip the lecture. The problems are easy and the grading is amazing. There'll be 4 quizzes and each quiz has 5 MC problems, but each problem worths 25 points, meaning that if you answer 4 problems correctly then you'll get full mark. And best 3 of 4 quizzes will be counted. Very easy to get full.

For written exam, the problem is a bit harder this year, but only if you understand lecture slides well, there won't be much trouble. This sem the exam was arranged on Canvas, the order of questions is random and as long as you switch to next problem, you are unable to modify previous answers. So some students were worried and didn't get good mark since they met difficult problems at the beginning, which definitely affect moods.

For project, you need to write the Arduino code of a car and let it run along the white line on the ground. The Arduino code obeys C/C++ syntax so it'll be much easy if you known C/C++ before. Two code test sessions has been arranged and during each session you can submit two versions of codes and TA will upload your code into the car and run it on the map. Unlike computer program, the car didn't run exactly the same each time, as there'll be many factors that can affect its preformance. So even though your code is completely correct, sometimes you'll also get a low mark. And that happens on myself, which is a pity. Actually no one can ensure the result, but this is the best way that TA can do so do not complain.

For the report, you need to describe what you've done in project and describe your code's logic by using flow chart and true tables. As long as you do it as required, you'll get full mark.

My score:
- Labs: 28.95/30 (I think I've done all of them right, and maybe sometimes they don't give full mark, but I'm not sure)
- Quizzes: 15/15
- Written exam: 100/100, Mean 66.55/100, SD 16.52/100
- Project: 6/20
- Report: 5/5
Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is not heavy at all. The labs are easy, as detailed instructions have been given. So it only takes less than 1 hour to finish your circuit and reports.
For final project, if you're familier with C/C++, then programming is easy for you. But you need to think a lot for designing the logic and think about special conditions as much as possible and this may takes a long time. 1~2 Weeks required.
There's not much new knowledge in lecture slides, so basically you don't need to spend lots of time for preparing the written exam.

reviews.author: AzzAzAAzzzAza
reviews.comment_content:
The main content includes the basics of circuits.
Also includes a few logics and Arduino programming.

The final project is to programme a car moving a specified path. Demo session performed on ZOOM
reviews.comment_teaching:
Some pop-up quizzes in lecture, so lecture is not skippable.
Professor Park has good knowledge in this area. However, his voice is very plane, it is quite boring to take the lecture.
The PowerPoint notes given are DESASTER. It has a horrible colour which makes you cannot focus when studying. Many ugly hand-written notes are included, spending meaningless time on figuring out the content.
reviews.comment_grading:
Labs: 30%
Quiz: 15%
Exam: 30%
Project: 25%

***I join this course during the Covid-19, not sure is there any difference compared to last few years

There are 6 labs in total; you have to build some circuits by TinkerCad. You have to show the results to the TA. Basically, you can get full marks if you follow the tutorial notes carefully. Also, you get 1 mark by submitting the summary sheet for every lab.

There are 4 pop-up quizzes in total. The 3 highest score will be regarded as the final result. All the questions are MCs.

The final exam is divided into 3 parts, MCs, Long Questions and circuit building. It is not an open book exam, and using the calculator is not allowed.

Well, as long as you spend some effort on this course, you are likely to get some marks. WHAT REALLY MATTERS IS THE FINAL PROJECT
you get 1% as long as you hand in the source code.
4% of the score depends on the report (as long as it meets all requirements, you get full marks).
20% of the score depends on how far can your car reach. Many students fail to get desirable marks in this part (very few information is given before the Demo session). Therefore, even though you perform badly in the exam and pop-up quizzes, you can get a good grade if you perform this well.

For my case:
Labs: 29/30% (Remember to submit the summary sheet ...)
Quiz: 9/15% (I guess the average is about 11-12)
Exam: 18/30% (I got 61/100 and the average is 67)
Project: 20/25%
And I got B+ as the final grade.
As long as your car work, you get a good grade.

Better have some programming background before you join this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
Spending time on lab: 1-3 hours/week
Studying + decoding hand-written notes: 1-2 hours/week
Final project: 4-5 hours in the project week

Actually, the time spent is acceptable. But you may feel overwhelmed when doing the work.

reviews.author: hj5k1od1
reviews.title: Not recommended to take it if it is not f2f
reviews.comment_content:
Some stuffs you learned in high school such as current, voltage, conductor, electron, resistance, power, energy, serial & parallel circuit, magnet, dc motor

Circuit components:
diode, zener diode, oscilloscope, breadboard, power supply , 555 timer, schmitt trigger, resistor, capacitor, counter, comparator, transistor, h-bridge

Others:
KCL, KVL, pn junction, boolean algebra, truth table, k-map, logic gate

Not included in the exam:
Sensor, arduino
reviews.comment_teaching: Since the content is not hard, so I just study them by myself and I don't know if the teaching is good or not.
reviews.comment_grading:
6 Labs : 30% ( 5% each )
4 Pop-up quizzes : 15% ( best 3 out of 4)
Exam : 30%
Project : 20% code 5% report

Everyone get full mark or almost full mark in labs & quizzes & report, so what affect your grade would be exam and project code.

The mean of the exam was 66.55 and the sd was 16.52.
Most of the question of the exam are easy except the KVL part which told you to solve 3 variables with 3 equations with ugly number.( But it turned out, even I couldn't solved it in time, I still got most of the mark)

The project code was a nightmare for most of us. We were given a circuit and base code, and we need modify the base code to make the car to finish a given track.
We only got 4 trial to test our code and for the other time, we have to imagine everything in our head.
The mean and sd were not released, but It seemed very horrible since even in the final demo, most of the people can't start they car properly, I am just lucky enough to finish the track.

If you like gambling, it is the course for you.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light, 1-2hours is for each lab
The content is not hard, I just spent 1 day doing revision for the exam
The project code is about 150~300 lines of code written in C.
It took me few hours to finish, but I know it took few days for someone, so it depends.

reviews.author: dodo
reviews.title: Ok and fun
reviews.comment_content:
This is a laboratory focused course. You will need to keep engaged in the lab as all materials of this course is orientated around the lab.

The lab required the student to build a circuit based on some transistor with fixed-function to propel a path tracking drone car. Some programming is required to modified the circuit.
reviews.comment_teaching:
OK.
TA of tutorial keep reminding the possible fault you will make in the lab.
Lab assistance is helpful.
reviews.comment_grading: This semester is special so I think it doesn't count to the grading nature of this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
moderate.
you will need to keep engaging into the lab.

reviews.comment_content: It is a good course for you to fist touch the area of robot programming and a little bit of circuit in reality.

reviews.comment_workload: The workload is fair for a 4 credit course. But the online project was really time-consuming as we could not test our code when we do the project by ourselves. We were only given 5 chances in total to test our code.

reviews.author: Frankie:)
reviews.title: A course emphasise on coding and logics
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers several introductory chapters to electronic engineering like:
Basic Physics equation like V=IR, P=VI.......
The function of Transistors, Diode, Zendor Diode and capacitors.....
H-Bridge
Kirchhoff's Laws KCL and KVL (core content of exam)
Sensors
Logic Gates (AND, OR, NOR, NAND......)and K-Map
Arduino code Programming of the car running in a given track map
Actually, you need to be interested in electronic engineering in order to get good grade
reviews.comment_teaching: My instructor, Prof Moss , is a nice and animable lecturer. He will explain everything in the lecture slides. Whenever students encounter difficulties or come up with some questions regarding the lecture content. Prof Moss will be more than willing to answer all of them one by one. So he is actually one of the best professors in this department. Also, Prof Song is also a good and friendly professor too as I heard this from my friends
reviews.comment_grading:
To be honest, the grading of this course is fair, here are the weightings of each section which accounts for your grade
online IPRS (count the best 70%)15%
Online exam 15%
Arduino Coding 20%(depends very much on luck)
project report 5%
Lab assignment 15%
Labs(1-6)@5% all 30%
Because of the ease of getting full mark in labs and assignments,you really have to score high with a view to getting a good grade
My Performance
Labs(1-6) all full mark 30%
Lab assignment 15/15 15%
online IPRS 75/100 15%
online exam 83.5/100 12.525%
Arduino Code 20%(perfect Run)
Project Report full mark 5%
My grade. totally
97.525%
A grade
i was just 0.5 short of an A+
reviews.comment_workload:
This is a 4-credit course , the workload is relatively heavy. one lab summary sheet per week, the lab assignment, which accounts for 15% of the total course grade, is quite hard, it is recommended that you should team up with friends and check the answer with them.

Also, when it comes to Arduino coding, DO NOT copy and paste your friend's code and simply hand it in. The teaching team will run a plagiarism test. Once they found a 100% similarity, you will receive Sanction.i have my friend being downgraded from B+ to C+.So I must stress once again that you must not copy your friend's code directly, else you will put you and your friends in peril

reviews.author: {Curly Braces}
reviews.title: A course that really needs some efforts
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers:
Basically most of the things taught in the DSE Physics electricity part
Pulse-Width Modulation (PWM)
Transistors and Diode Circuits
H-Bridge
Kirchhoff's Laws (KCL and KVL)
Sensors
Logic Gates and Karnaugh Map
Basic Arduino Programming

And you have to use all these pieces of knowledge to complete the final project.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Song teaches with a quite 'special' way I would say. I remember that there is one lecture that he specially made a question that gives a red packet to the first student who answers it correctly. (As a celebration of Lunar New Year)
At the last lecture, he even prepared a special lecture that is useful in daily life.
In other times, he explains the concepts clearly and in an understandable manner.
reviews.comment_grading:
The Course mark is as follows:
In-lecture quiz: 15% (Getting a total of 70% is enough for full marks in this area)
Lab Demos & Summary Sheets: 30%
Lab Homework: 15%
Exam: 15%
Final Project: 20% (Project Demo) + 5% (Report)

Generally fair, however getting A-range in this course may be more difficult than other courses.

Getting full scores on quizzes, lab demo, lab homework and the project report pretty much is a must if you want to get B range or above. The exam and final project demo is mainly where the grades are differentiated.
reviews.comment_workload:
The final project might more difficult than what you have expected. Since the project demo is where the grades are distinguished, you have to pay more efforts to it if you want a better grade!
For the final exam, you may want to make sure how circuits work if you want high marks. KCL and KVL would require skills to solve 3 unknown linear equation system.

Note: Be reminded that this semester is held at online mode due to COVID-19 outbreak, so the opportunities allowed for the final project may be more than this semester.

reviews.author: Luosh
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers wide range of topics but all are simple. Listed as follow:

1.Basic electrics
2.Basic electrical components
3.PWM control
4.H Bridge
5.Basic logics
6.Basic Arduino

Although all of the topics are really easy, I think it still help you have an overview on what u may encounter in your rest of the university years. If you have no idea about your major selection, this is a course recommended.
reviews.comment_teaching: I believe the professor have enough knowledge on this course, but sometimes he just can't express it in detail maybe because his English is not really good.
reviews.comment_grading:
3 pop-quiz
4 Labs
Midterm
Final report(originally it is project)

I got almost full marks in every aspects, the only mark I lost is one of the Labs.

Overall, it is a good-grade course. But just as I mention over and over agin, this course is quite easy and everyone got really high score and the mean is really high. I heard someone got 92.5 in the last but only B+.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not heavy. Only the final project or final report are slightly annoying. But It can be done really soon if you understand all the materials well.

reviews.author: shhh
reviews.comment_content:
There are only 18 lectures in the first 10 weeks. The titles are:
Course Introduction and Basic Electronics
Basic Electronic Components

PWM Motor Control

I think most of them are quite easy

The lectures are quite boring. You can skip them if there are no quiz. The tutorial are also optional. You can probably self-study. They both have heavy Chinese accent. it's a little bit difficult to understand what they speak.

Lab assistants and students helpers are very helpful.
reviews.comment_grading:
EXAMS: 1 lab midterm (20%) and 1 written exam (20%)

POP-UP QUIZ: 3 Pop-up In-class quizzes (open book), only the top 2 max scores will be counted (10% total)

reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is light.
No preparation is actually needed for lab
The only work is just the project.

reviews.author: sliangal
reviews.title: Interesting and good grade
reviews.comment_content:
The lecture begin with basic physics which studied in secondary school and then move to logic circuits and introduction of electronic components. Tutorial will review the content of lecture and help you  understand what you will do in lab. In labs you will gradually manufacture your "breadboard" week by week, finally the breadboard will be used on your car.

The lecture will end around one month before the end of semester,  
and then it's time for you to do final project, you need to finish your breadboard, assemble your car and do some easy programming.(Actually I think you can cope with it even you don't know programming, be relax)
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecture is a little boring but the explanation is adequate. Tutorial is helpful for lab.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab reports (20%)
Written Midterm Exam (20%)
Lab Midterm Exam (20%)
Pop-up Quizzes (10%)
Final Project  (30%)

Lab reports:6 reports in all, quite easy, be careful then you can get full marks.
Written midterm exam: Not hard if you understand the content in lecture.
Lab midterm: Redo some experiments which have been done in previous labs, and answer some questions relative with it.
Pop-up quiz:Quite easy, just for take attendance, two highest grades of three will be taken.
Final project: Not difficult, but you need time to test you car. In this
semester it was changed to a report due to the situation, the almost all students get full mark.

My grade:
Lab reports: Nearly full mark
Written midterm: 84/100
Lab midterm: 19/20
Pop-up quiz: 20/20
Final project: 30/30 (We use the demo video instead because we finish the project in advance)
Overall grade: should be 96+ which is calculated by myself
Letter Grade: A

Review: I think the grading scheme is kind(at least better than many other classes). It can be better if we have a real demo in final project.
reviews.comment_workload: Light workload, I think you can follow well even if you just look the ppt by yourself, but do notice the pop-up quiz in lecture.

Easy course, generally good grades, but you need to be EXTREMELY careful with anything that might affect your grade. EVERY POINT COUNTS, since the course is so easy, everyone's getting high scores. If you want to get anything above A- you should aim for 95+.
And last but not least, take the in-class quizzes seriously.

Perhaps her accent is a bit difficult to understand at first, but I got used to it at last.
reviews.comment_grading:
The project demo was replaced by the project proposal this year so the overall grade is largely dependent on LAB MT & Written MT. Because you will have enough time in LAB & Written exam (LAB: 75 mins, Written: 100 mins), so the scores will reflect what you've learned. There will be Additional Exercise uploaded to Canvas before MT, and it's quite similar to the real question so it's worthwhile to have a try!

The final lesson of tutorial and lecture are quite important.They will give you a bit hints for you to achieve the perfect run.

reviews.author: LolSpacer69
reviews.comment_content:
- Learn about some ICs (e.g NE555 timer)
- Some basic physics
- Programming using Arduino
- Build a robot car with your partner using a breadboard
reviews.comment_teaching: ok la.
reviews.comment_grading:
Exams: 1 Lab Midterm (20%) and 1 Written Exam (20%)
Labs: 6 Lab Assignments (20% total); minimum 4 labs’ attendance to be eligible for final project demo.
Quiz: 3 Pop-up In-class quizzes (open book);  only the top 2 max scores will be counted (10% total) (Stick with your enrolled lecture session, no marks given to any attempt at the other two)
